liceman looked about, and the shopman put the boots on the counter for the policeman—they talked a bit—he then said, "I suspect these two of stealing the boots"—I said, "I have no one to wear the boots—I have had no husband for two years"—I opened my cloak—I had nothing to cut them with—I have six small children.
Recommended to mercy by the Jury.

DAVIS—
GUILTY . Aged 39.—
Confined Nine Days.

NOWLAN—
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.

208.
BENJAMIN JACOBS was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of November, at St Botolph-without—Aldgate, 1 neck-chain, value 3l. 10s.; 2 rings, value 3l.; and 2 pairs of ear-rings, value 3l. 10s.; the goods, of
Lydia Emanuel, in her dwelling-house.

LYDIA EMANUEL . I am a widow, and keep a clothes-shop, in Harrow-alley, Houndsditch, in the parish of St. Botolph-without—Aldgate; it is my dwelling-house. On Saturday, the 10th of November, before I went out, I went into my bed-room, opened my drawers, and locked them all safe—I left this property in the drawers—I went out between six and seven o'clock in the evening, leaving a female servant at home—I was not out half an hour before my grandchild came and called me—I found my house full of people, and the room in great confusion, these things were gone, and others packed up ready to take away.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How came you to go to your drawers before you went out? A. To take my spectacles out—these two rings were in my beaufet, and the ear-rings also—they were all in one little drawer.

MARTHA DODD . I am the prosecutrix's servant. I recollect her going out-her bed-room is up one pair of stairs—when she went out I bolted the street-door after her—I cannot tell how any person could have got into the house, or whether they got in before or after she went out—I was sit
ting—atneedlework in the kitchen, which is level with the ground, and heard a noise up stairs—the stairs come into the kitchen—I thought it was the cat, and I called her, but instead of her coming down stairs, she came to me from under a chair—I then sat still, and heard another noise—I took no notice, and I soon after saw a light pass by the crack of the bed-room door—I thought my mistress had left the light up stairs—I went to go op, and, in going up a few stairs, a man opened the bed-room door, with a can
dle in his hand—I was so frightened that I stopped a few minutes, and the man too—I never shall forget the look he gave me—I got out as soon as I could, and gave the alarm, and the man got out of the front bedroom win
dow—I hallooed out in the street, and persons came to know what was the matter—I told them, and ran up stairs, and saw my mistress's things, the plate and wearing apparel, all down on the ground, and packed up, the window-curtains torn down, and eight or nine locks broken—the prisoner was taken that night, and I swore to him that night—I am certain he is the man I saw—he could not have got in after my mistress went out, be
cause the door was bolted.

Cross-examined. Q. How could you see the light under your mistress's door? A. The bed-room door was right opposite me—I can see from the kitchen up to the bed-room door—there are but a few stairs—there is no door to the kitchen—I could look right up to the bed-room door-a great many persons came into the house, but they were pretty well all my mis
tress's family, her children and grandchildren—the prisoner looked at me so hard I thought he would have pierced me through—I was very much flurried indeed-as he jumped out of the window the tail of his coat caught my comb, and broke two teeth out.

ANDREW DACEY (police-constable H 94.) I received information, and took the prisoner at ten o'clock that night—his dress was described to me, and I knew him previously to this—I took Dodd to the station-house—she swore to him positively, and said, if it was her last words on her dying bed, that was the man.
Cross-examined. Q. Where did you take him? A. In Wentworth-street, about five minutes' walk from the prosecutrix's—there are slop-shops and old clothes-shops in Harrow-alley.

GUILTY . † Aged 19.—
Transported for Ten Years.

209.
GEORGE DEANE was indicted
for a misdemeanour.

JAMES REVELL . I am shopman to John Sherborn and others, oil and colourmen, at No. 321, Oxford-street. On the 16th of October the pri
soner came to the shop, and wished to know the price of shellac—I told him—he said he would take 121bs. weight, and 21bs. weight of white gum—I asked if they were to go down to Mr. Frinneby—he said, "Yes"—I should not have given him the goods unless they were to go to Mr. Frin
meby—I
knew the prisoner as his servant—we deal largely with him, and for that reason gave him credit.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Were the goods made up? A. Yes, and I offered them to him—he said he must have a bill, or it would not be right.
FREDERICK RICHARD FRINNEBY . I am a brush-maker. The prisoner had been my servant—he was not so on the 16th of October—I did not send him for these things—he did not go by my orders.
WILLIAM KING (police-constable G 120.) I took the prisoner, and the shopman asked him whether he was prepared to pay it, or could he pay it.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he ask him if he was the man that came? A. Yes—I said I would have no compromising—he then said he would give him in charge.

GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Three Months.

div0.p: Second Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
210.
THOMAS FREEMAN was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
MR. DOANI conducted the Prosecution.

CHARLOTTE MATTHEWS . I am single, and live in Perry-street, Somers town. On the 3rd of November the prisoner came to me—I was not ac
quainted with him, but I had seen him once before, twelve months ago, when he had brought me a letter from a friend—he did not bring any letter on this occasion, but he said since I had seen him last he had been a voy
age to Sierra Leone, and had seen my friend on board the Dolphin, to which he belonged—he produced these papers to me, and said there was 22l. due to him on them, which he was to receive at Somerset-house on the 15th of November, and asked me if I could advance him 1l. till the Monday, when he would repay me—my sister gave him 15s. by my direc
tion—I cannot read myself, but the papers were read over to me by a friend in the prisoner's presence—I believed them to be genuine, and ad
vanced him the money in consequence of his representing that they were so, and that he belonged to the ship he named, otherwise I should not have dope it—he left the papers with me as security—he dined with me on the Sunday after, and on Monday I went with him to Somerset-house—he went into the gates, but whether he went into any office I cannot say—when he returned he said it was the 5th of November, which was a public holiday, and the money could not be paid till the Monday following—I went again with him next day—he went into the same place, and said the clerks were engaged, or gone to lunch, and he could be paid in an hour—these are the papers he gave me—I have never had any of the money back again. (The papers being read, one purported to be a certificate from the London Dock Registry, of good character, to Thomas Freeman, on a voyage to Sierra Leone, in the Edward Mills, Captain Harry, and entitling him to 15l. 5s. wages; and the other a document from the Admiralty, entitling Thomas Free
man, able-seaman, to 22l. 5s. prize money, for service on board her Majesty's ship Dolphin, Edward Blankley, Commander.)
THOMAS KING WALCOT . I am a clerk in the Admiralty. I have the

muster-books of the Dolphin—I find on them the name of Thomas Free
man—he was paid the residue of wages due to him, on the 13th of Novem
ber, 1837, amounting to 6l. 8s. 3d.—that was all that was due to him on account of wages—I know nothing of any prize-money being due to him—he was on board from the 17th of September, 1836, to the 18th of Sep
tember, 1837—he was in fact on board only till August the 22nd, 1837, but was paid up to the 18th of September, by a regulation of the service—the Dolphin was not paid off—he was discharged—he afterwards entered as a volunteer on board the Electra, on the 31st of January, 1838, but ran away from her on the 14th of September, at Portsmouth, and having done so, he forfeits all wages or prize-money that might have been due to him—one of the papers produced relates to the merchant-service, and I know no
thing of it—it would not entitle him to any money from us—the other pur
ports to be a certificate from the Admiralty, but it is a fabrication alto
gether, such a certificate would never be given there, it would not entitle him to receive any wages.
Prisoner. I received some other wages from the Rolla. Witness. I know nothing about that—the Rolla is not mentioned in these papers.

JOHN MATSON . I am a clerk in the Prize-office, Somerset-house. There does not appear to be any prize-money due to the prisoner-all that he was entitled to was paid—this document, dated from the Admiralty, is a forgery—Captain Blankley, whose name is stated as Captain of the Dol
phin, was not the captain of that vessel at that time.

HENRY DEWDNEY . I am Superintendent of the Seaman's Registry in the Commercial-road. This document appears to be dated from my office—there are no such parties as stated in this, in any way connected with our office—it is a fabrication-our papers are printed—this is written—it it a fabrication from beginning to end, the name of the master, ship, office, and every thing.

ISAAC MARCH (police-constable E 41.) The prisoner was given into my custody on the 12th of November, in Tottenham-court-road, by Mr. Mat
thews, for obtaining money under false pretences—he said he would pay the money back again.
(The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that he had no intention of defrauding the prosecutrix, that he had been twenty years in the navy, and had a wife and two children.)

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Confined One Year.

(There were two other indictments against the prisoner for similar of
fences.)

211.
EDWARD BUTTON was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
MR. DOANE conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM FLOOD . I am a porter. On Thursday afternoon, the 15th of November, the prisoner who lives at Mr. Campbell's, at the Crown, in Butcher-hall-lane, told me to go for twopenny worth of cantharides—I got it at Mr. Watkins's, and gave it to him—he gave me 2d. for my trouble.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Where did you give it to him? A. In the shop—I always knew him to bear the character of a decent, well
conducted person.
MARY ANN WELLS . I was living at Mr. Campbell's—the prisoner was waiter there. On Friday morning, the 16th of November, I breakfasted

at half-past nine o'clock—my master and mistress, and the prisoner and his wife had had their breakfast together soon after eight o'clock-just before I had mine, I saw the prisoner go up stairs as I was coming down—he had an opportunity of getting to the coffee before I had—I afterwards drank a small portion of it, and it made me ill—I saw Mr. Hadlow the doctor.

Cross-examined. Q. You only drank very little? A. About half a cup—my sister took a little—I was about my business next day—I had had no quarrel with the prisoner—we were on friendly terms—his wife was living in the house at the time as servant, for about a fortnight—she went away the evening this happened—about half-a-pint of coffee was made for the second breakfast.

ELIZABETH WELLS . I am sister of last witness. I went up stairs to Mrs. Campbell, when I found out the disagreeable taste in the coffee, and told her of it, but she had drank of it then—she only had about two table spoonfuls—she was in a delicate state of health before.

JAMES CAMPBELL . I keep the Crown. On the morning of the 16th I was with my wife when she took the coffee—it made her ill, and I had the prisoner taken into custody—he said he had given it out of a lark.

HENRY HADLOW . I am a surgeon in Jury-street, Aldgate. I was called in to attend Mrs. Campbell, on the morning of the 16th of Novem
ber—I saw the coffee, and there was cantharides in it sufficient to produce an injurious effect to any one taking it—Mrs. Campbell was very seriously affected by it for twenty hours, and is an invalid still.

Cross-examined. Q. She was an invalid before? A. She was—I could not tell what quantity there was-twopenny worth mixed in half-a-pint of coffee would produce most serious consequences, if all taken by one person-Mary Ann Wells and Mrs. Campbell were both ill, and it was necessary to apply powerful remedies—Mrs. Campbell labours under a stomachic disease, not connected at all with the occasion of my being called in to attend her in this case, but it was aggravated by this—she is now under my care.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 23.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Tweleve Months.
Before Mr. Recorder.

212.
JOHN HUTTON STALWORTHY was indicted
for embezzle
ment.

ISAAC BRYANT . I was shopman to Mr. Henry Moyce, King-street, Convent-garden; but I have left—the prisoner was also a shopman in his service. On Saturday evening, the 27th of October, after lighting the gas, I went to the desk and counted the money on it—there were three half-crowns, a fourpenny-penny, and 3s. or 4s. in copper—I left it on the top of the desk—the prisoner was in the shop at the time-a woman came in, and was served by the prisoner—I saw her pay him 1s. 6d. and 3d. in coppers—the prisoner went to the desk and put 9d. there—the shilling was put somewhere else—I went to the desk directly after, and there was no shilling there—I asked the prisoner how much money he had taken of that lady—he immediately said "1s. 9d."—I said, "Where is the shilling? there is no shilling there"—he said, "Perhaps it is under the coppers, per
haps it has fallen down behind the desk"—he was going round to see himself, but thinking perhaps he would put the shilling there, I pulled him back a little, and there was no shilling there when I went round-when

my master returned I told him what had happened-no one but the pri
soner had been to the desk, from the time I had left the half-crowns and coppers there, nor from the time the prisoner went there till my master came.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How long had the prisoner been in your master's employment? A. A fortnight—he had very likely been gaining his master's good will very fast—I know he had—I am not in the employment now—I was discharged—my master did not direct me to watch the prisoner—I told Johnson, on Saturday morning, of my intention of doing so—I had not heard that any money was lost—I had reason to watch him, for on the Wednesday or Thursday before, I saw him drop some money from his hand, and look very much confused—that was the reason I watched him—the 1s. 9d. is entered in the book, but very likely that was put down afterwards—he did enter it—he asked me to go with him to the desk, and look behind, to see if the shilling was there, but I thought he would put it there—I went directly after, by myself-Johnson was serving a customer in the shop at the time—I had had no words with the prisoner—I was by the side of him when he put the 9d. on the desk—I went directly after and saw no shilling.

Q. If there had been one, you had the opportunity of removing it? A. Yes, but I did not—I left a month after this, because I was ill—I was out one night-two gentlemen assaulted me, and bad to pay 5l. each for it—I slept Saturday night in the station-house—I was with my sister and another young lady, in George-street, Strand, and they wanted to take the inside of the pavement—I was eight or nine months in the prosecutor's employ—I was discharged about a fortnight ago, on a Tuesday night—the assault was on the Saturday—I was ill on Saturday, and did not go back till Tuesday—I went to the theatre on Monday night, instead of returning to my master's—it was very foolish of me—I was out Saturday night, Sunday night, and Monday night, without giving him notice—I told my master I had been ill—I was discharged for staying away.

THOMAS JOHNSON . I am in the employ of Mr. Moyce. On Saturday evening, the 27th of October, I counted the money on the desk, after Bryant—there was three half-crowns, a sixpence, a fourpence, and some coppers—these told me to count it—the prisoner was serving a customer while I did so—he took 1s. 9d. of the customer, and went and put some money on the desk—these went and counted it—I went afterwards, and found there was one shilling short of what the prisoner had taken—I did not remove any thing—I am quite sure there was no shilling there when I went—these might, if so disposed, have taken the shilling off before I went.

Cross-examined. Q. Were you not very much surprised at Bryant ask
ing you to go and count the money? A. Yes; he told me on Saturday morning that he suspected him—I had a slight suspicion myself, as be several times dropped money, and said it was very slippery—he said so in Bryant's presence—these was discharged for being out two or three nights—these asked the prisoner what he had taken from the customer, and he said, "1s. 9d. "—I did not look to see whether he entered it in the book—he ought to have done so, but it is sometimes not done when we are very busy—my master had not desired me to watch the prisoner—he never intimated any suspicion about him, or complained of money being deficient.
JAMES WESTON (police-constable F 62.) I apprehended the prisoner, on
the 27th of October, at his master's, about a quarter before nine o'clock in the evening—I searched him, and found on him a five-shilling-piece, two shillings, and threepence in halfpence.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe he declared he was perfectly innocent? A. He did, and said it was a shocking thing that he should be taken up on such a charge, when he could have money at any time from his uncle.

HENRY MOYCE . The prisoner was in my employ for a fortnight I was very much pleased with his conduct up to the present time—I gave him into custody from information received from Bryant—I had no alter
native—I have a leaf here which I saw taken out of my book—it is dated, "October 27th"—here is 1s. 9d. entered as received by the person enter
ing it—I cannot tell whether it is the prisoner's writing, but I believe it is—there are eight or ten entries after it—I dismissed Bryant for being out on Saturday, Sunday, and Monday nights—I said to him when he came back, "What do you mean by this?"—he said, "I was ill, and could not come"—I said, "Don't tell me so, for I have proof that you were at the theatre on Monday night"—I had received a message from a young woman on Monday night, about eight o'clock, that he was very ill in bed, and could not come, and that very night he was at the theatre—he wished to stay with me, but I said on no account would I have him, on account of his mis
conduct—he had 25l. a-year—the prisoner had 30l.—these did not know what the prisoner had.
NOT GUILTY .

213.
DENNIS M'CARTHY was indicted
for assaulting
Janet Temple Smith, a girl seven years of age, with intent to ravish.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Nine Months.

214.
JAMES LANGRIDGE was indicted
for assaulting
Elizabeth Whitaker, with a like intent.

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

215.
WILLIAM HARRIS was indicted
for assaulting
Margaret Weston, a girl eleven years old, with a like intent.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Twelve Months.

216.
JOSEPH ALEXANDER TREVETHEN was indicted
for a mis
demeanor.
MESSRS. CLARKSON and BALLANTINE conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM RAFFEHEEPS . I am clerk to Mr. Ramsbotham. About the 10th of September the prisoner called at my master's counting-house, (I did not know him before) and wished to purchase some low-priced sherries, saying he had been referred to us by Mr. Lindsay—I told him Mr. Rams
botham was not at home, but he had two or three parcels that were just landed in the London and St. Katherine Docks, and I appointed him to meet Mr. Ramsbotham at the Docks—Mr. Ramsbotham could not go, and

I went and met the prisoner at the Docks, either the same day, or the next—I showed him a parcel containing four butts, eight hogsheads, and four quarter casks—he inquired the price—I referred him to Mr. Ramsbotham—he said the quantity was immaterial—he talked very largely, and, I think, said he was a man of property—he made an appointment to see Mr. Ramsbotham.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Did you hear what passed between Mr. Ramsbotham and him? A. No; I heard him say the deed in question was worth four or five hundred pounds—I do not know which—it was not three thousand pounds.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Is Mr. Lindsay a person known to Mr. Ramsbot
ham? A. Yes, and known at the Docks.

CHARLES WHEEN RAMSBOTHAM . I carry on business in Dunstan-court, Mincing-lane. On the 11th of September last, I went to St. Katharine's Docks in consequence of an appointment made by my clerk—I saw the prisoner there—he was a stranger to me—he said he had been told that I had some wines on the quay, which would suit his purpose, and he wished me to make a bargain with him for them—he wished to offer me a price for them—he had already seen them with my clerk in the morning—he looked at them again, and said they would suit him—he talked about other wines, saying he wanted to purchase very largely of other qualities—atlast it was decided that he would have these four butts, eight hogsheads, and four quarter-casks, which formed one parcel, and he would call on me next day about it—he told me he was a man of property, but was not much known in the market—that he had lately had cash left him, and he in
tended to pay cash for every thing he bought—he called on me next morn
ing, between ten and eleven o'clock—the price was then named, and fixed at 17l. per butt, which would be altogether 170l.—I asked him for a reference—he told me he always wished to satisfy parties he did business with—that he intended to name a party he had been travelling for, but he had had a dispute with the house, and consequently would not wish to refer me there, but he stated he had lately come into possession of property, which he had received as heir to his father—I told him he had said he in
tended it to be a cash transaction—he said he intended to pay cash, but that that day he was short, and he would give me the title-deeds of his property, of which he had lately come into possession, as security for the payment of the money in the course of a few days, and he produced to me this deed—(looking at one)—he particularly pointed out to me this part, that it was to be held by Thomas Trevethen, his father, his heirs and assigns, as absolute property, and stated that the property was waste land at the time the document was written, but it had been built on, and was then worth 500l., and in accounting for the indorsement on it, he said that a short time before it had been in the hands of some party for an advance of 200l., but as this would only be for a few days, it was not worth while indorsing it again—he depo
sited the deed with me as security for the payment—he then asked me for the transfers, as he could not get the wines, or transfer them to any other party before I had transferred them to him—I ultimately gave him the wine warrants, in consequence of the representations he made with respect to this instrument—I had refused to do so before—I parted with them be
lieving what he said was true—I have never received any cash since—I had occasion to leave town on the Saturday after I had parted with the warrants, the 15th, and Mr. Ramsay, a friend of mine, undertook the management

of my business in my absence—I mentioned to him the transaction be
tween the prisoner and myself, under what circumstances I had agreed with him, and what had been deposited with me—I never authorised Mr. Ramsay to take bills of exchange in payment from the prisoner for the wine—it was arranged in the first instance that I was to be paid immedi
ately-subsequently, in the after part of the day, when the prisoner had got possession of the warrant, he said he thought he probably should not be able to pay cash so soon, but part of the property that would come to him on the 29th of September would be in cash—I remonstrated against this delay, but as I was obliged to leave town immediately, I had no alternative—some of the wine is gone from the Docks.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you not had some of the warrants back again? A. No, not any, I believe the officer has three warrants for hogsheads, but they form a very small part of the whole, which was twenty hogsheads—some bills of exchange were sent under an envelope, during my absence, to my counting-house, but they have never been received as payment—some of them are on a Mr. Bragg of Bristol—Mr. Bragg has not given me up any warrants—Mr. Bragg waited on me some time ago, and made an offer to give up part of the wines he had, on my cancelling the bills against him, which he stated had been obtained by Mr. Trevethen under false pretences, but I have since discovered that Mr. Bragg has got an ad
vance on those wines, and they are no longer in his power to de
liver to me—I understand Mr. Bragg is a man of no responsibility at all—he told me he could not pay 6d. towards the bills—he did not tell me his wife was a person of property—he said she had no property—the prisoner told me that Mr. Bragg's wife was a person, of property—that he had got a bond on her property—I believe he said so when we first talked about the parties to whom the wine was going—when I found that the money was not forthcoming, I called on the prisoner to know what he had done with the wines, and he gave a kind of history of what he had done or was going to do with them—he mentioned Mr. Bragg as a person to whom he had parted with some—he did not name him as a person whose bills he would give me—decidedly not—there was no talk about bills at all—he men
tioned Mr. Bragg as a highly respectable tradesman of Bristol-now I happened to know Bristol very well—I referred to the name of Bragg, and asked who he was—he said he had been for a long time with a house he named, which an intimate friend of mine had lately established—that he was going to be one of his greatest friends and correspondents, and that he had got security from Mr. Bragg to the extent of 4 or 500l. in a bond, I understood him to say, of some property of his wife's or family's—the bills on Mr. Bragg were one of 81l. and one of 70l.—the wine he had was worth 51l.—the prisoner was apprehended on the 29th of October—I delivered him the warrant on the 11th of September.

Q. Was there not a further shipment of wines agreed for between you and the prisoner? A. Not agreed for—he wished me to make an agree
ment for them, and of course if he had paid me the cash for these I should with pleasure have gone on in further business with him—this deed was not given as a deposit for any further shipments-nothing of the kind was mentioned—one of the bills that were sent was on a Mr. Phillips for 19l.—Mr. Phillips has never called on me and offered me the money on my taking off the discount—I never heard any thing of the kind—I have seen Mr. Phillips—the bill is payable at Smith, Payne and

Smith—the object of his calling on me was to tell me it was at Mr. Trevethen's request that he accepted the bill, and that he made it payable at Smith's, at Mr. Trevethen's request, because it would look better—his object in calling was not to pay the bill—he never offered to pay it, on my making a reduction.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you at any time from the beginning to the conclusion, agree or consent to take bills of exchange for your goods? A. Certainly not, of any kind whatever—nor did I authorise any body to do it for me.

ANDREW RAMSAY . I am a wine-merchant, and live in George-street, Minories. About the 13th or 14th of September, I was requested by Mr. Ramsbotham to take charge of his business during his absence for a few weeks—I did so, and saw the prisoner at Mr. Ramsbotham's counting-house—I told him that in undertaking the management of Mr. Rams
botham's business during his absence, and he telling me he had transactions with him for four butts of wine then on the quay, I wished to know his account of it—he mentioned something about giving bills, and some were afterwards sent to the counting-house—I had received no authority from the prosecutor to take bills in payment—I never received them in pay
ment, only as a deposit.

Cross-examined. Q. A bill is always a deposit—I suppose you took them, and if they were paid it was all right, if not, yon held the man re
sponsible who had the goods? A. The bills had four months to run—I could not have taken them in that sense—the prisoner was to pay the amount by the 9th of September, but in the mean time he deposited the bills as security—the prisoner told me that he had given Mr. Ramsbothan security for 500l.—the prisoner brought one bill to the Dock in the first instance—that was on Bragg and Co. of Bristol—I took that bill, but not in payment—I told him at the time I took it, that I wanted the money—I cannot tell on what day it was—it was between the 14th and 29th of September—he again repeated that on the 29th of September, he would bring the money—he had the warrants in his possession at the time—I saw him about the Docks everyday, and was every day urging him for the money-very likely eight days might elapse between his giving me the first bill and my receiving the others—he gave me another on Mr. Bragg, which I discovered was an altered bill—I recommended him to draw it afresh for his own safety—he said he had no change to purchase a stamp, and Mr. Ramsbotham's clerk gave him the money for it—he afterwards brought the bill properly drawn and left it with me—I have the bills here—they are drawn at four months.

Q. Is not a bill at four months in the wine trade reckoned cash? A. Certainly not—nor at three months-not even bankers' bills, if they have only one month to run—I gave the bills to Mr. Ramsbotham's clerk to lock up till his return, and I was urging in the mean time payment of the money from the prisoner.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you tell the prisoner you would not consent to receive them as payment for the wines? A. Undoubtedly, in the most pointed manner—I explained to him that I merely received them as a de
posit for the money, he assuring me that the 29th of September would be the latest period of his being in ample funds to pay the money.

HENRY LE GRICE . I am an attorney at Bury St. Edmunds. I pro
duce the proceedings in a commission of bankruptcy against the prisoner,

on the 8th of September, 1835—the usual parts of them have been en
rolled, the fiat, the adjudication, and the appointment of assignees—I have retained possession of them—I know the prisoner to be the person against whom the fiat was issued—(looking at the deed given to the prosecutor)—I know the property comprehended in this deed—there was no statement in the'balance-sheet of the prisoner of his having any such property—the assig
nees afterwards discovered that he had a reversionary interest, on the death of his mother, in the property, and they put it up for sale—the prisoner knew of that—he called on me after I had been down to Bury and seen the property, in 1837—I then questioned him about it, and he said he had forgotten it—he gave that as a reason for not having put it in his balance-sheet, and he gave the same answer to the commissioners—I was present when he was examined at the Insolvent Debtors' Court—he was discharged under the Insolvent Act—the date of his examination before the Commissioners was the 24th of March, 1836—he afterwards called on me, previous to the sale, on the 23rd of May, 1837, and knew it was to be sold—it was put up with some copyhold property, and fetched about 75l. the whole—there were some buildings on it, I believe, partly stables—(looking at a bill)—this is one of the bills of sale—the property formed part of lot 3, and was sold for 75l. to Mr. John Trevethen, the prisoner's brother.

Cross-examined. Q. Do not you know it was bought by him for the prisoner? A. I do not know it—the conveyances were made out to Mr. John Trevethen—we should not have had them made out to a man who was a bankrupt, and had not received his certificate—I have known the pri
soner ten or twelve years, living at Bury St. Edmunds—he left very shortly after he took the benefit of the Act—I believed him respectable up to the time of his bankruptcy.

JAMES SMITH (police-constable H 113.) On the 30th of October I re
ceived the prisoner in custody from the prosecutor—on our way to the sta
tion-house he asked me with what he was charged—I told him, for obtaining wine by false pretences from Mr. Rarasbotham—he said he wished to have the business settled, and he had thrown himself in the way on purpose—he gave up some papers, among which were these three warrants, for a hogshead of wine each.

MR. RAMSBOTHAM re-examined. This is the deed the prisoner showed me, and this was the part he particularly pointed out—(reads)—"to be vested, &c, for the benefit of Thomas Trevethen, his heirs and assigns, as his private and absolute property"—it was believing what he stated about that which induced me to part with the warrants—he never told me it had been sold to his brother, or that his brother held it—he never mentioned his brother—he said he was heir to his father—he did not mention his mother at all.

JOHN TREVETHEN . I am the prisoner's brother, and have been a builder at Bury St. Edmunds for twenty-seven years. I bought the property in question by the prisoner's request, I believe for 155l. but I do not know—I never saw the documents—they are principally copyhold, except two small pieces of field—I bought all the property he had under his father's will, at his request—I bought some lots, and Mr. Wayman bought some—I only bought his interest in it—I know there is a cottage on it, worth 4l. or 5l. a-year, and there may be about half an acre of land, but I forget, having been away so many years—I refused to buy it when he first asked me—the property is not

conveyed yet—I bought it by auction—I told him at the time I would not let him have it till he was in a condition to receive it—Mr. Le Grice has the cottage—I have not paid the 155l.—I paid a deposit—I should say the two included are worth 400l. or 500l., but I know nothing about it—it was sold as it was, under lease to Murty, but I never saw the deed—it has not been offered for my signature.

COURT. Q. Had your brother any communication with you, to autho
rise the deposit of this document, when he was in treaty for the wine? A. No, he had not—he solicited me to purchase on three occasions—I believe the property was advertised for sale, and not sold, at first—I saw that two pieces of freehold land were left out, which belonged to him, and that made me look after it—I informed Mr. Le Grice's clerk, and they were inserted afterwards—when he was able to receive the property he was to have it.

GUILTY . Aged.—
Confined Six Months.

div0.p: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
217.
ANN NORMAN, alias Streeton, alias Hathaway
;
MARY ANN GRAFTON ,
CHARLES FOSTER ,
THOMAS GUY, alias John Thomp
son
; and
JAMES HOBBS , were indicted for
conspiracy.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the Prosecution.

ROBERT NATHANIEL BURTON . I am a corn-factor, and have an office in Bush-lane. I have a cottage at Finchley, which I was desirous of letting—the prisoner Norman called on me at my office, and represented herself by the name of Ann Streeton—she said she had seen my cottage, and wished to take it—we very shortly agreed about the terms, which were 40l. a-year—she said she had lived at the New-forest, Southampton, for some considerable time, and that she would give me a reference to her late land
lord's brother, whom she had a house of there—that he was the best possible reference, as he knew how she had paid her rent, and she referred me to Mr. Hobbs, (the prisoner,) New Manor-street, Chelsea—we came to an agreement, and I wrote it out, stating the terms for three years, for which time she was to take the house—I wanted her to take it for five years, but she said it was impossible, she would not be tied to a house so long—she called for the agreement, and said she must have pos
session immediately, the following day or two, as her furniture was on its way from Southampton, and she must have the house to go to at once, which I agreed to—on the second day, when she called to sign the agree
ment, she asked if I had a wine-merchant, and I named my wine-mer
chants, Messrs. Gill & Co. of Mark-lane—this was on Monday or Tues
day, I think on the Friday following I received information, and went down to my cottage on the Sunday morning—I found there the prisoners Norman, Grafton, and Foster—I asked Norman how she could account for her conduct—she said it was all over now, and there was no help for it—I found them nearly destitute—there was no furniture in the house—they had used the kitchen drawers for tables and chairs, and there was a dirty old bed on the floor, which was all I could see—they were taken on the Wednesday, by the policeman, to Edge ware, and I think from there to prison.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You found them in a desti
tute state? A. Yes, in a room with a great number of old beef bones, and other things.

JAMES PARKER . I am brought from White Cross-street prison. I did live at No. 41, Ely-place—I called at the request of Mr. Burton, on the prisoner Hobbs, at New Manor-street, Chelsea—(I cannot recollect when it was)—I found Hobbs at a beer-shop—I told him, that Mrs. Streeton, of the New Forest, Southampton, had given a reference to him as to her respectability—he said he did not like to give characters in general, but the was a very respectable woman—I asked him if she had rented a house of his brother for seven or eight years—he said she had, and had always paid her rent regularly—I asked him what establishment she kept—he said, a phaeton, a pair of ponies, and I am not sure whether he said three or four servants—I told him she was about taking a house of Mr. Burton, at 40l. a-year rent—he said she had rented houses of double that rent, and he should have no objection to let her one, only his own were not in a sufficient state of forwardness—he told me I should find her a close-fisted woman, but I should not have to call a second time for the rent.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you make any memorandum of the conversation? A. I did not—I afterwards inquired, and found that Mr. Hobbs passed himself off as a builder, but he was not known as such—I inquired of Sergeant Tedman, but did not make inquiries in the neigh
bourhood—I am quite sure that Mr. Hobbs did not say that Mrs. Streeton had told him she kept a phaeton—he did not say that he had seen it—I am not in Whitecross-street for debt, but through a mistake in a legal process—I have made application to a Judge to get out, and shall be out in a few days.
GOODMAN. (Looking at an agreement)—This is my name, as a witness to this agreement—I saw Mrs. Norman sign it, in the name of Streeton, on the day it bears date.
(The agreement was here read for letting the house for three years certain,
and was dated 27th October, 1838.)

WILLIAM SMALLPIECE WHITTINGTON . I am clerk to Messrs. Gill, wine-merchants, of Mark-lane. The prisoner Norman called at my em
ployers' counting-house on the 29th of October—she said she had taken a cottage of Mr. Burton, at Finchley, that he had named us as his wine-mer
chants, and she wanted some wine—I asked what wine she required, and she gave an order for three dozen of sherry, three dozen of port, and two gallons of brandy; and here is a subsequent order, in her writing, on the 1st of November, for one dozen of madeira, and two gallons of ram—the amount of the whole was 24l. 3s. 6d.—she said I was to put down the prices as low as possible, as she always paid cash for the goods—the goods were sent by Drewett, the carrier—I went down to the house on a Monday, I think, the 5th or 6th of November—I found the house in custody of an officer, but I could not find the bottles or wine, or any part of the spirits-from information I afterwards received, I went to a house in Bridge-water-square, where I found some wine, and two gallons of rum in a jar—I could identify the jar of spirits as one we had forwarded to Finchley, and our cellarman could identify the wine—the bottles had been sealed when they left our counting-house, but the seals had been cut off close to the bottles.
COURT. Q. What house did you go to in Bridgewater-square? A. No. 15—the landlord came for me, and I went with him.

CHARLES DREWETT . I am the Finchley carrier. On the 31st of Octo
ber I received two hampers from Mr. Gill, the wine-merchant—I delivered them at Rose Cottage, in Ballard's-lane, Finchley—I received a note from the servant at the house, which was the prisoner Grafton—I took the note to the wine-merchant, and left it there, on the 1st of November, and on the 2nd I took down from there two stone bottles in a basket, and delivered them at the same house.

CECILIA DREW . I keep a grocer and chandler's shop at Finchley. On the 27th of October I sent my young man to Rose Cottage for orders, and I afterwards sent some goods there—on the Thursday following I went to the house—the amount of my bill at that time was between 6l. and 1l.—I saw the servant Grafton first—I asked to speak to Mrs. Streeton—the servant told me she was engaged, and I was to go up in an hour afterwards—I went then, and saw Mrs. Streeton—I told her I had a large bill to pay, and I should be glad if she could pay me my bill, or part of the money—she said if I would send the bill on Monday she would pay me on Tuesday—that she had taken the house of Mr. Burton for three years, and she had given him a reference to the landlord of the house where she had lived for the last eight years—I bid her good afternoon, and we had no more conversation—there were some orders came to me on that Thursday, but I only sent part of them; and on the Saturday there were orders, but I did not send them—on the Monday I went with the bill—I saw the servant (Grafton) at the window—she took the bill of me—Mrs. Streeton also came to the window—she told me I need not wait, she should pay the bill, but should not pay it then—this is a copy of my bill—(look
ing at it)—it amounts to 8l. 11s.—I went to the house with the policeman the same afternoon—there were some stone jars and white jars of mine there—Mrs. Streeton said what there was left she would give up to me—some plums, and currants, and soap, and lump sugar, of mine, were brought down to Finchley, and shown to me by a young man.
COURT. Q. Who was it you saw these things with? A. Henry Stuckey.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Before you called at Mrs. Streeton's, had you delivered all these goods, except about 1l. worth? A. Yes—I called for orders at the house, they did not make application to me—the goods I got back was about 1l. worth—Mrs. Streeton did not tell me that she had given a reference to Mr. Hobbs, but to some place that Mr. Burton was satisfied with, and he had let her the house—I went by what she said.

HENRY STUCKEY . I am shopman to Mrs. Drew. On the 27th of October I received an order from the prisoner, Mrs. Streeton, for candles, soap, sugar, tea, and other things—I delivered them at the house, to the servant, Grafton—on the 28th, I took some more goods, which I delivered to Grafton—on the 30th, I delivered some more things—they consisted of blacking, plates, a dish, vinegar, nails, and other things—on the 31st, I delivered 1/4 cwt. of sugar, some butter, ginger, bacon, honey, and other things; and on the 1st of November, some scouring-paper, jars, and other things—I delivered them all to Grafton—I had very little conversa
tion with her—I asked her where she came from—she said, "From South
ampton"—I asked who her mistress dealt with there—she said, "Mr. Rymer, a cheesemonger, of East-street, Southampton"—that the family
had been in the habit of dealing with him for eight years past—she said they expected the remaining part of the family in a few days.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. I am afraid a great deal passed between you and this young woman? A. No, Sir—I do not make a practice of talking with all the servant-girls in the neighbourhood—I took a walk in the garden with Grafton, but that was at the time I was stationed in the house with the policeman, to take care of the property.

EVAN EVANS . I am a greengrocer, and live at Finchley—I deal in coals and greens. An order was left at my house, when I was not at home, for a sack of coals, to be taken to Rose Cottage—I took the coals to the cottage—I saw Grafton and Foster—I had the coals in two sacks—I shot one down in the little passage, and the other I left in the sack, in the scullery, according to their request—I received an order for grapes, apples, greens, and such things, from Grafton and Foster—they were acting as servants in the house, to the best of my knowledge—I delivered goods to the amount of 3l. 15s. 8d.-both Grafton and Foster said I was to take my bill on the Monday, and I should be paid on the Tuesday following, at nine o'clock—I went upon the Sunday afternoon, like the rest of the sufferers, the tradespeople of Finchley—I cannot say how many there were—I believe I heard Foster say, it served us right for not going on the Friday night.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Who was the man you heard say this? A. I believe it was the boy Foster—I overheard it, and I believe it was him—I did not see him then—I had seen him a very little time before—I was listening, with my ear close to the door, the same as all the rest were, when it was said—I am sure I heard-it, and I believe, by the voice, it was Foster—I did not see him at the time-Norman, Grafton, and Foster, were in the house at the time—they had locked themselves in—I went up to see the last of them, like all the rest—I did not go to have them taken up.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. You had seen Foster shortly before you heard this? A. Yes—I and my brother tradesmen were outside the house—I had seen Foster at the back of the house—I could see into a small room which they were in at that time—I saw Grafton and Foster, and Mrs. Streeton came into the room—she said, "You shall have your money, whatever becomes of the rest, as you are a poor man, with a large family"—there was no other man or boy in the room, from the time I saw Foster there, till I heard them talking—I knew his voice, by his coming to my house for goods.

WILLIAM JAMES WRIGHT . I am a butcher, and live at Finchley. I did not know Norman till she was taken, but Grafton used to come to me, and order beef-steaks, mutton-chops, roasting-beef, and other things for her mistress, Mrs. Streeton—my bill came to 1l. 15s. 11d.—on the Sunday after the goods had been delivered, I saw Bond, who is since dead, in the act of loading a cart at the back-door of the prisoner's cottage.

THOMAS RAKE . I am a livery stable-keeper, and live in the Curtain-road. I know the prisoner Guy—I always heard of his name being Thompson—he lived at Highgate—I do not know what he is by business, he never told me—he always had a green bag in his hand, whenever I saw him—I let him a chaise, about three or four months ago—I cannot say when was the last time—it is about three months ago—I never put it down, when persons pay as they go on—he said he was going to Edmonton and

Enfield—I believe he never mentioned Finchley to me—I do not recollect that ever he did—it was on a Sunday he had it last—I was not bound in recognizance to appear before the Grand Jury—I never set my hand to any paper—I did not abstain purposely from going before the Grand Jury—I did not know any thing about it—I did not go before the Grand Jury till I was sent for.

Q. On the last time, on the Sunday when he hired a chaise of you, what was it for? A. It was a cart he hired last to go to Highgate—he said he was going to take his family out—he did not say any thing about his children, nor about Finchley, I swear that—he hired the cart between eleven and twelve o'clock, to take his family up from Highgate, not to fetch his children from Finchley—that I swear solemnly.

COURT. Q. Were you sworn before the Magistrate? A. Yes, and what I said was put down in writing—I did not swear he was a tailor—I said I thought he was a tailor, as he had always a green bag with him.

Q. Did you swear before the Magistrate that it was between ten and eleven o'clock on Sunday morning, and that he went to fetch his children from Finchley? A. I do not know the time—he did not say "his children," he said his "family from Finchley"—he did not on that occasion pay me ready money, he did before—he now owes me 12s. 6d.—he hired the chaise in the name of "Thompson," and I thought that was always his name—I booked the 12d. 6d. to Thompson.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDSRGAST. Q. You took no particular notice of what be said? A. No—he had hired a chaise before, and paid me for that, and in consequence of that I let him have the horse and cart—I thought his name was Thompson—that is all I know—I cannot swear that he told me his name was Thompson—I did not write any name down, and I cannot say what it was—I thought it was that.

Q. You do not mean that you put down the name of Thompson? A. Yes, I put that name down—I did not take any address of him—I only put down the name of Thompson—that was the name I knew him by—I had only seen him once before—I do not know what was in the green bag.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did he answer to the name of Thompson, both times? A. I did not ask him his name.

JOSEPH HIGGS . I am a horse-patrol. In consequence of information I received, I went on Sunday, the 4th of November, to Rose-cottage, Bal
lard's-lane, Finchley, about five minutes before six o'clock in the evening—when I got about 200 yards beyond the cottage, I saw a cart—the pri
soners Guy and Mrs. Streeton were in it—there was on the cart the name of "Thomas Guy, East-street, Walworth," chalked on a piece of leather, and on the other side of the leather was printed, "Thomas Rake, 138, Cur
tain-road"—the chalked side was outwards—I spoke to Guy, and asked him whose cart it was—he said it was his, and he was hired to bring it down to Rose-cottage to take the things away which he had in the cart—I asked him his name, and he refused to tell me—I found in the cart about 1 cwt. of coals, some meat, and a box, some candles, some flannel, some tin-dishes, sugar, tea, a dripping-pan, a baking-dish, two chairs, and part of a pig's head—these things were wrapped in a kind of horse-rug in a pan, which covered over the coals and the things that were in the cart—the prisoner Norman did not say any thing at that time—I took them back to the King of Prussia public-house—I then pulled the leather off the cart, and saw Rake's name on the other side of it—I put the horse and cart up

and locked up the property—Mrs. Streeton said if I doubted that she was the person that lived in Rose Cottage, she would take me and show me, and the said the things were her property—(when I saw the things in the cart they were coming from the cottage)—I went to the cottage with her—she knocked at the door—the female servant came down, let her in, and she shut the door—on the next day I took Streeton, and Grafton, and Foster into custody there, and searched the house—there was a mattrass, three pillows, two wooden chairs, and an old table; a quantity of crockery packed up in a box, and coal-sacks with different names on them; some plates and dishes, two casks which had had beer in them; some candles, sugar, cheese, soap, and a few small articles of grocery, which Mrs. Streeton was giving up to Mrs. Drew, when I went in—I asked her what she was doing—she said she was giving them up, and she was quite willing to give up what was in the cart—I was desired by the Magistrate, to watch at Clerkenwell New Prison after the prisoners were committed—I saw a wo
man speak to Mrs. Streeton, and in consequence of what I observed pass, I followed that woman to No. 15, Bridgewater-square—the woman went into that house, and I watched there till the next morning—I then sent for Mr. Gill, the wine-merchant, and he procured Herdsfield, the City officer.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you take Hobbs? A. Yes, at Great Manor-street—I took him before the Magistrate, and brought him back—I charged him 80s.—I did not tell him if he did not pay I would have his goods—his brother paid it.

THOMAS HERDSFIELD . I am a City officer. I was sent for to No. 15, Bridgewater-square, by Mr. Gill, on the 18th of November—I found there ten bottles of wine, and two gallon stone bottles—I believe there was brandy in one of them—Mr. Gill identified the stone bottles immediately—I gave up the wine and the stone bottles to Mr. Whittington—I found a quantity of grocery things which were identified by Drew—I delivered them up to a person for her—I found some ale and beer which was identified by Mr. Thompson, and the body of a chaise in the front parlour, and the wheels, springs, and shafts, in the yard.

ROBERT TUBBS , Esq. I am a Magistrate of Middlesex. I have a cot
tage at Harlesdon Green and five acres of land attached to it—I know the prisoner Ann Norman—she came to me in that name, early in the month of August—she treated with me for the possession of that cottage as a tenant—I have the memorandum which I made with her—I let the house to her at ninety odd pounds a year, for three years—the memorandum was signed by her in my presence—the cottage was occupied by her from the Saturday till the Tuesday week—I then received a letter inclosing the key, by the parcel-delivery company—the key opened the cottage—I had delivered it to Mrs. Norman-a few days after I received the letter I went to the cottage—there was no furniture there—the acres of land were let to her with the cottage—she described herself as a widow lady of property, who had been living some years at Bath, that she had several children, that they were all provided for, and she wished to be in the neighbourhood of London, for the purpose of educating the children—I said it was necessary that I should have a reference—she said she could give me twenty references, but she thought she could not do better than to give me a reference to the brother of her late landlord at Bath, under whom she had lived five or six years, who was a builder at Fulham, and she named a man of

the name of Hobbs, who was building some houses at Fulham, and said I should find him at Stamford Brook-lodge—I drove to Fulham, and found some houses being built, and upon inquiry I found the prisoner Hobbs—I told him the object of my visit, and he said he knew Mrs. Norman very well—that she was a widow lady, and had been residing at Bath—that she had had a house of his brother's five or six years, and that she had always paid the rent punctually—I told him my object in asking the reference was, that she was about to take a house of me at 96l. or 97l. a year, and I asked him if she was a person in those circumstances that would warrant that proceeding—he said, yes, she was, and that he only knew one thing against her, and that was, that she was rather near in money matters—he either said "near" or "close"—Mrs. Norman called on me the next morning or the morning after, and in consequence of what Hobbs had said, I let her the house.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Are you sure that Hobbs said this? A. Yes, quite sure—I got the key back in about ten days.

JOHN LOWE . I am a grocer and live at Acton—that is about two miles and a half from Mr. Tubbs's cottage, at Harlesdon Green—on the 18th of August last, I saw the prisoner Norman—she told me her name was Nor
man, and she had just taken Mr. Tubbs's cottage—she came to me for tea and sugar, and grocery—I supplied her with goods that day to the amount of 30s., and I continued to serve her on the following week—I know the prisoner Foster—he was in the habit of coming to my shop frequently for goods of the same description as Mrs. Norman had—I remember on the Saturday after Mrs. Norman had come to me, Foster came and ordered some goods—he had walked down, and he wished me to give him a ride back again in my cart, which I did—he admired the horse, and said his mistress had got a pair of horses, a very fine strapping pair, sixteen hands high, that they had ordered hay and corn of Mr. Billington, a neigh
bour of mine, that the coachman and cook were coming on Monday, and I was to be sure to bring my bill in on Monday, and it would be paid on the Tuesday—the same afternoon the prisoner Grafton came for more goods, and it being a wet afternoon, she requested a ride back also, and I took her in the cart—I rather grumbled about going up so often with the things, it being a great distance, and wished them to give me the order in the morning and I would execute it—she told me her mistress came from Bath, and the cook was down there then—that she was coming up on Mon
day, and then she would come with the orders, and would not give me so much trouble-Grafton said she had lived with her mistress six years—when Mrs. Norman came to the shop she wanted every article good, but did not say any thing about price—but Grafton said her mistress was not very particular about price so long as the things were good—the amount of the goods they had of me was 14l. 6s. 8d.—it began on the 18th of August and ended on the 27th—they had of me tea, sugar, butter, soap, blacking, bacon, candles, and other things, and a great many things which I did not sell, I went and got for them.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDEKHAST. Q. Did you not ask for her custom? A. No, sir—she said she was the lady that had taken Mr. Tubbs's cottage, and I said I should be happy to have her custom—she told me she had got Mr. Tubbs's cottage, and I went to Mr. Tubbs's, but it was not from what he said that I trusted her—I had trusted her before I saw him, but not to the whole of this amount—she came to me on a Saturday, and I saw Mr. Tubbs one day in the following week.
COURT. Q. Should you have trusted her if she had not been at that house, and if you had not heard from the servants about the horses and other things? A. No, I should not.

JOSEPH CLARK . I am a journeyman butcher, in the service of Mr. May, near Harelsdon-green. He supplied goods to the two servants, Grafton and Foster—I gave them some meat and some grocery things—I do not know to what amount, nor for how long—I delivered several joints of meat.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You went to the house? A. We sent down, and took orders.

JAMES POPE . I live at Harlesdon-green, and am a milkman. I know the prisoner Norman—I do not know the other female prisoner's name, but she was the person who was in the house, and I know Foster—they came to live in Mr. Tubbs's house on the 18th of August, I think—I sent to the women in care of the house to say that I should be happy to serve the lady, and then they sent to me, I think, but I was not at home—I sup
plied them with cream, and butter, and eggs, up to the 27th of that month, to the amount of 1l. 17s., odd-Norman left the cottage on Mon
day night, the 27th—I saw her in the morning of that day, and took my bill—she said I had done quite right to bring my bill, and she would settle with me on the morrow morning—I saw Grafton and Foster there, acting as servants—I asked Foster what his mistress's name was—he told me her name was Norman, that she came from Bath, that she was a widow, that there was a carriage and horses, and daughters, and that he expected them to arrive every day—I went up on the Tuesday morning, and they were all gone—I had taken them a roasting pig on the Sunday morning—I took it up in a dish, and delivered it to Grafton—I asked her for the dish, and she said I might leave it; and one day, when I took some butter, I left a basket there, which is a usual thing-people sometimes say, "You may leave it," and we do.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDSRGAST. Q. You do not blame them for giving you their custom when you call for it? A. No—I did not go to them for custom myself, but my mother did—I was not at home when the lady arrived, but my mother was let know that the lady had come, and then she went-Foster did not tell me that the horses were sixteen hands high—he did not say he had seen them—he did not say any thing to show that he had not just been engaged.

WILLIAM BILLINGDON . I am a corn-dealer. My account of goods supplied to Mrs. Norman, at Mr. Tubbs's cottage, between the 21st and 25th of August last, was 10l. 0s. 4d.—I never saw Mrs. Norman myself—after they left the cottage I fetched the sacks away—they were corn sacks, marked with my own name—I found them after they left in the kitchen—there did not appear to have been any horse there at all—there was a small quantity of straw in the coach-house place, or stable, which had been packed up with other goods.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You sent somebody to ask for their custom directly, did you not? A. Yes.

HENRY HOLFORD . I am a boot and shoemaker, and live at Acton. In consequence of a communication made to me by Mr. Billingdon's man, I went to the cottage at Harlesdon-green. I saw there the prisoner Grafton, who was acting in the capacity of a servant—she wanted me to measure her for a pair of shoes if I could get them done by Saturday—it was on

Wednesday or Thursday, the 22nd or 23rd of August, that I went—I pro
mised to get them done, and measured her—she asked me if I had a card—she said the family were coming on Friday, and most likely she could get me their custom, and they would be good customers, as they were a large family—on the Saturday morning I sent the shoes—they were a pair of Spanish slippers-in the afternoon Grafton came to my shop and wanted me to go over there in the evening to measure their young ladies for some shoes—she said the family was come—she looked in my window and said if I had a pair or two made I might take them with me, and I was to be over there by seven o'clock—I went over, and took with me seven or eight pairs of shoes and some boots and clogs—I saw Grafton—she took the shoes and boots and clogs into another room, Mrs. Norman came out of the room and said I was behind my time, and one of the family was gone to bed, but if I would leave the goods, if either pair fitted she would return the others by Mr. Billingdon's cart on the Monday morning—she said there was none small enough for one little girl, she would get me to measure her for a pair and bring them the beginning of the week—I left my goods and never got any of them back.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. How old was the little girl? A. I do not know, perhaps about eight years old—I did not have the little girl taken up—I offered to go after my goods, but Mrs. Norman promised to send them back on the Monday—I left three pain—I should have been glad to have sold as many as I could if I had got the money for them—I did not want to trust them—I did not expect that all the three pairs were for one person—I saw two small children.

JAMES WARD . I am journeyman to Mr. Holford. I remember re
ceiving a note from Foster while they were living at the cottage—he brought a note, as he said, from Mrs. Norman, for a pair of shoes—I opened the note and let him have a pair—this is the note—(read)—"Mrs. Norman requests Mr. Holford to let the bearer, her servant, have a pair of boots or shoes, which he has that will fit, and a pair of walking boots or shoes, the size sent—the young man will explain."
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. If the size had suited he might have had more? A. Yes.

JOHN PONTIFEX . I am a copper-smith, and live in Shoe-lane, In September last, I had a house and fixtures at Winchmore-hill—I adver
tised it in September—the prisoner Norman called in the name of Mary Ann Norman, on the 22nd of September, and said she had seen my house which was to let at Winchmore-hill, and thought it would suit her, if we could agree for terms—I said my terms were 40l. a-year, but I expected the fixtures to be paid for—she said, if the fixtures went in with the rent, she should have no objection to take it—I told her I should have no objection to that, if I had a good reference—she said she should take it for three years, and she would give me a good reference—she paused a little, as though considering who she should name, and she said, "Mr. Pontifex, I think I cannot name better than my old landlord, that I have rented under many years, which is Mr. Hobbs, a builder, in Stamford Villa, Fulham-road"—she begged I would send as soon as possible, as she had another house in view—I sent that day-in consequence of what my young man told me, I agreed with her on the 24th for three years, at 40l. a-year—she occupied my cottage from eight to nine days—on the 8th of October, I received a letter with the key-before taking the house, she asked me if

there were good tradesmen about Winchmore-hill—I said yes—she asked if there were good coal-merchants—I told her there were persons that could serve her with coals—she asked who was my coal-merchant—I said Dyer—she said, would I be so kind as to order some for her, and I ordered a ton, which were sent in the next day—she asked who was my wine-merchant, and I told her what little I had, I had of a person at Enfield—she asked me his name, and I said Smith—she asked if there were any good grocers—I said yes, one very good shop—she asked where I dealt—I told her at Mr. Barrough's, at Hatton-garden—after that, Mr. Barrough called on me—I went on the 9th of October, to see the house at Winchmore-hill—the fixtures were left, but no furniture.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You did not want furniture? A. No, I was glad to get my house and fixtures, but I should rather have had a good tenant.

JOHN SEARLES LADE . I am clerk to Mr. Pontifex. In consequence of directions from him, I went to the prisoner Hobbs, at Stamford Villa, in the Fulham-road—I saw him, and asked him if he knew a lady by the name of Norman—he said he did—I asked him if she was likely to pay the rent of a house of 40l. or 50l. a-year—he said yes, she was a very respect
able' person—that he had a very good reference from his brother, who lived at Southampton—he said that I had no cause to be afraid of the rent, as that would be always certain, and I had no cause to go twice for it, that she kept a phaeton and pair—he said she was very close in her dealing—I communicated to Mr. Pontifex what he told me.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Where was it you saw Hobbs?—A. At Stamford Villa, Fulham-road—it was an unfinished house—I did not count how many unfinished houses there were—I should think they would let for about 40l. a-year—there were workmen engaged upon them—the conversation lasted about ten minutes perhaps—he was not doing any thing—I met him at the door.

THOMAS OSLIFFE . I am in partnership with John Udall of Winchmore-hill. We are grocers and general-dealers—On the 29th of September, the prisoner Norman came to our shop—she gave the name of Norman, and ordered several articles, which were sent down—here is our bill, amounting to 5l. 10s. 1d.—she said she had taken a house of Mr. Pontifex, and she would pay for the articles as we sent them down if we chose, but that she generally paid weekly—she had a book, and we entered several things—the prisoner Foster fetched several articles—the book was cast up on Satur
day night, and they were to be paid for on the Monday—Foster came, I believe, every day—I made up the book by the direction of Foster—he said he only knew the family since they came there—I was to go down on the Monday with the bill, but Mr. Pontifex's servant came to tell us they were gone—there was 1lb. weight of tea, 3lbs. weight of sugar, blacking, brooms, &c., and such like things.

JOHN SELL . I live at Winchmore-hill, and am a carpenter and iron-monger. I know the two female prisoners, and Foster—on Monday the 1st of October, I saw Foster sweeping the gravel walk of the house at Winchmore-hill, where Norman lived—I asked him if the lady was within, and if I could see her—he said, "Go to the door if you please, and you will see the servant"—I went and saw Grafton—I asked if I could see the lady—she said, "You cannot see her for an hour, if you come again you can see her"—I went, and Mrs. Norman made her appearance—I asked her if there

was anything wanted in the carpentering line—she said she had received a card from Mr. Pontifex, and that I was the person she should employ, and she ordered two deal boxes to be made—she showed me a box standing on a chair—they were to be made similar to that, only larger, deeper, and a drawer at the bottom of each—she said she should wish to have them as early as I could possibly get them done—she said she wanted an ironing-board made and fixed in the scullery, and a clothes-horse and window-blind—she said there would be a corn-bin wanting, but she must have the other orders executed first—she told Foster to show me some jobs that were wanted to be done in the stable, Foster went with me to the stable, and gave me orders to make a couple of shelves ten feet long, to go behind the door—he wanted them in the course of the week—I asked him if they wanted any thing in the ironmongery way, and Grafton told me there were many things that were wanted in that line, and the would come up to the shop, and give me the order—in about a quarter of an hour after I returned home, Grafton came to the shop, and brought a list of the articles that she wanted—there were pails for the stable and house, dripping-pans, safes, and other things, amounting to 2l. 17s. 9d.—I delivered them the same evening—she gave me the measure by a piece of string for a brass fender, and fire irons, and a tea-kettle were ordered—I saw the dripping-pan afterwards in the cart, going away—I saw the house several times after they had left—there were none of these things left in the house or stable.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Who first applied to you? A. I applied myself.

WILLIAM STILLING . I live at No. 11, New Inn-yard, Shoreditch. I know Norman and Guy—Norman came to me as his wife—they went by the name of Mr. and Mrs. Thompson—I had a house, No. 15, Bridge water-square, that was to let—Thompson and the woman came about a fortnight before last Michaelmas—Thompson said he thought the house would suit him—he asked what rent it was—I said, "58l. a year"—I wanted 10l. for fix
tures—he said he would not pay for any fixtures, he would give me the rent—he took it for three years—he said his goods were coming from Man
chester, and he was in the Manchester trade—upon this arrangement I asked for a reference, and Thompson wrote down this reference for me—this is what he wrote in my presence and hers—(read)—"Mr. Hobbs, builder, Eagle New Tap, Manor-street, Chelsea"—I went to Mr. Hobbs, and saw him at the Eagle Tap, in New Manor-street—I asked him if he knew Mr. Thompson—he said yes, very well, he was a very respectable man, he had a good deal of property, and lived in a house of his brother's at Man
chester for ten years, and always paid his rent very well—I asked him if he would be afraid to let him a house of 50l. or 60l. a-year—he said not for 100l. a year, he should be sure of the rent—he said I need not be afraid of letting him the house, I should be sure of the rent—in consequence of that I gave him possession of the house with Norman, who had passed as his wife—I have not got possession of the house now—there are some of the children in it now.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDEROAST. Q. Your rent is not due? A. No, I have not demanded any rent—some person came and took away a great quantity of goods from the house—there are five young children there—the eldest says she is seventeen years old—the others are much younger—I am sure Norman was there when he said he was her husband—I will
undertake to say that—I saw her with him two or three times, and when they came and took possession.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. When was it you went to Hobbs? A. About ten days before Michaelmas—I saw him at the bar of the Eagle tap—it is in a street going out of the King's-road.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Had they possession of your house from just before Michaelmas up to the present time? A. Yes—there was no furniture in the house—there are two or three old chairs and a table, and some
thing of that kind.
WILLIAM STEVENS . I am a slater, and live at No. 16, Charles-street, Middlesex Hospital. I have known Grafton and Foster about four years—they have always gone with me by the name of Thompson.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Do you keep a house? A. I have got a house—I do not keep the house there.

JOSEPH HIGGS
re-examined. I took Norman into custody on the 5th of November—Hobbs was taken on the 19th—there had been an examination of Norman before Hobbs was taken.

(George Smallwood, a builder, at Walham Green; William Shepherd, of Lisson-street, Lisson Grove; George Upward, Kent-road, builder, and—Rule, of the Lion brewery, Coppice-row, gave the prisoner Hobbs a good character.)

NORMAN—
GUILTY . Aged 49.

GUY—
GUILTY . Aged 48.
Confined Two Years.

HOBBS—
GUILTY . Aged 58.

GRAFTON—
GUILTY . Aged 21.

FOSTER—
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Six Months.
Fourth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

218.
JOHN GREENO was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
MR. HORRY conducted the Prosecution.

SARAH WARE . I live in Gravel-lane, and am the wife of James Ware, a seafaring man—he has been absent a considerable time. I have known the prisoner a good while by coming down to the King William—he repre
sented that he knew the law—I had a young man named Moore in trouble, and the prisoner said he would do all he could for me—I was at Lambeth-street police-office, when Moore was examined—the prisoner came up to a young woman who was with me just outside Lambeth-street office—Moore was at that time in custody—the prisoner spoke to her, and asked me what I was crying about—I said, "About a young man that was in prison"—he asked me what about—I said, "About a watch"—I saw him again after that—we went to a public-house and had some porter—I saw him again on the 8th of October, which was a week afterwards—he asked me to go with him to get the depositions—I paid him on that occasion three shillings—he told me to come up to the Old Bailey with him, as he was going to get two subpoenas—I went home to get some money, and then returned down here—I got some money—he asked me for 5s. to get two subpoenas—I gave it him—he went away for seven or eight minutes—he then re
turned and said he could not get it without I gave him another shilling—I gave him the shilling to finish paying for the two subpoenas—he said it was for that purpose—he returned with two long pieces of paper and a piece of parchment—the papers appeared to be new ones—they were quite

clean—the parchment appeared to be quite clean—it was straight, not folded at all—he gave me the parchment, and put the two pieces of paper in his coat pocket—I still stopped at the George public-house, Old Bailey—I folded the parchment up at the George, and put it in my bosom—after that I went to the King William, at Shad well—the prisoner asked me to let him look at the parchment to show to a person—I gave it him—I saw him again the next morning—I came up again to the George—before we went into the George, I said, "Where is that piece of paper I gave to you last night?"—he said he had given it to me—I told him he had not—when we got to the George, he asked me for 4s. 6d. to get another original, as the other one was lost—he said he must get a new one—I gave him two half-crowns in order to get a new one—I believed what he said, and that was the reason why I parted with my money—he went away—he told me I could go with him if I liked—I came into the Court, and he left me at the bottom of some stone stairs—I saw him again in about two minutes—he said, "It is all right, I have got one"—I went back to the George—after that he showed me a piece of parchment, and said he had got it—that piece was folded the same way, as far as I can judge, as I had folded the one the night before—it seemed to me to be the same, because it was rather dirty—the piece of parchment that I returned him the night before was dirty, by being folded and putting it down my bosom—I gave the money to the prisoner for the purpose of getting another, and no other purpose whatever.

JOHN JONAS . I am a clerk in the office of Mr. Clark. It is my duty to deliver subpoenas to persons applying for them—I have referred to the list of subpoenas issued last Sessions—I find one subpoena and two copies issued in the name of Moore, and that is the only one issued in that Sessions in that name—the charge for a subpoena is 2s. 6d., and the two copies 1s., which would be 3s. 6d.—I should think these two copies were issued from our office—I filled up the subpoena—I did not issue more than one.

Cross-examined by MR. PATNE. Q. You delivered one original sub
poena and two copies? A. Yes—I keep an account of all the subpoenas I issue.

MR. PAYNE to SARAH WARE. Q. Who was the subpoena given to? A. I did not see him give it to any body—he did not give it to Mr. Wig
gins—Mr. Wiggins looked at it—when he came down the stone stairs he said he had got a new one, and when he got to the George, he laid the parch
ment on the table, and Mr. Wiggins looked over it, but did not take it in his hand—it was folded in the same way as the first—I had kept it about two or three hours the night before—I said it was dirty when he showed it to me afterwards—I was sitting on one side of the table in the tap-room, and he on the other—he did not pull out a piece of parchment and give it to Mr. Wiggins—I have never said so—I am twenty-two years old—I was married twelve months ago, at Stepney-church—my husband staid about two months with me—I have never seen him since—he is on board the Donegal—he does not send me any of his pay—Moore was a friend of mine—I have never had any quarrel with the prisoner—I was not angry with him on account of Moore being convicted—he never laid out any money for me to pay for any cab—when he asked for the 4s. 6d. he said he was going to get a new original—the waiter and I, and another young woman, and Mr. Wiggins's brother, were in the public-house with the prisoner—I was at four or five different public-houses with the prisoner—he went into the prison to Moore, at my desire, to take him a clean shirt—Mr. Wiggins, the
brother of the other Mr. Wiggins, Was the person I employed in the last case.

MR. HORRY. Q. When did you first make an agreement with Wiggins about getting counsel? A. After the prisoner said he had lost the original—I was present when Moore was tried—the witnesses did not appear for him.

JURY. Q. When were you first acquainted with the prisoner? A. Down at Lambeth-street—but I had seen him at the King William before—I have always treated him at the public-houses I have been at with him.

SAMUEL WIGGINS .
