I am a tailor, and live at No. 6, Sidney-place, Sidney-street, City-road—I was in the George on Thursday, the 18th of October, and saw the prosecutrix, the prisoner, and another young woman—I saw the prisoner come in, stand at the comer of the box, and ask for 4s. 6d., to get a subpoena, in the room of the one he had lost the day before—she gave him two half-crowns—he said, "You may as well give me a crown," as she had only got the two half-crowns—they both went out—he came back in ten minutes or a quarter of an hour—the friend who was with the prosecutrix asked him if he had got it—he said yes, it was all right—he threw it on the table, and the prosecutrix said, "In my opinion this is the one that I folded up last night"—she said she thought it was the same she had given him the night before—I said, "What writing is on the back of this?"—he said, "You b——y fool, cannot you read?"—I said, "No, nor any body else."

Cross-examined. Q. How came you to be there? I had made a pair of trowsers for a gentleman—I do not interfere in the defence of prisoners, my brother does, and when he is not here, I sometimes give answers and sometimes go down to the George—the prosecutrix did not give the sub
poena to me—I have not had a quarrel with the prisoner—I never saw him before then—I did not tell the Magistrate this—I was not asked—I looked at the back of the paper—I have worked for Mr. Berdoe, of Gos
well-road since last April—I made part of a great coat with another man—we work at home, because he has not convenience on his premises.

PHOEBE FORDHAM . I am bar-maid at the Mahogany Bar public-house, in Wellclose-square—before the last Old Bailey Sessions the prisoner called and asked if I remembered seeing two men, and serving a glass of rum-and-water the week before, and whether the old man was drunk—I said "Yes, he was drunk"—he asked if I would attend at the Sessions—I said no, I could not—he said, if I would not attend by fair means he would make me, and in the evening he brought down a subpoena, and left it—this is the subpoena—I then said I could not attend—he said if he could do without me he would, but he would let me know—this subpoena is the same with respect to the writing as when I received it—it has got dirty since.

MARY PYKE . I am a widow, and live at No. 17, Gray's-alley, Wellclose-square, and am a haberdasher. One day, before the last Old Bailey Ses
sions, the prisoner came and asked me if two men were in my shop on Saturday night—I said, "What did they want?"—he said, it was not Saturday last, it was Saturday week—I said, "What did they want to buy?"—he said, "Nothing"—he said it was a coloured man and a sailor—he asked me to go to the Old Bailey, on behalf of Thomas Moore—I said I was a widow with four children, it was inconvenient for me to attend—he said if I would not attend he knew what to do—he brought me a paper previous
to that, and wanted me to sign it, which I refused to do—he afterwards gave me this subpoena—I did not attend.

JAMES BAKER . I am potman at the George, Old Bailey. I remember the prosecutrix and the prisoner being at our house before the last Sessions—I saw the prisoner receive 6s., but I heard no observation.

ROBERT DAVIS . I am an officer of Lambeth-street Police-office. I apprehended the prisoner on Friday, the 9th of November—I asked him if he knew a man of the name of Moore, who was committed from our office last Sessions for stealing a watch—he said, "Yes"—I told him he must consider himself in custody for having obtained some money from a woman, a friend of Moore, to obtain subpoenas, and draw out a brief—he said, "Is that all? I got the subpoenas at Mr. Clark's office, and can prove it"—I then told him he was charged with having obtained money for a second subpoena, having stated he had lost the first—he said, "That is not true, but I suppose it was some money that she lent me at the Jolly Sailor."

SARAH WARE
re-examined. I never lent the prisoner any money at the Jolly Sailor—I lent him half-a-crown and one shilling at the King William, on the 17th of October, the day he got the subpoen A.
JURY. Q. Did he state for what purpose he borrowed that money? A. No; he said he would give it me before he went away in the evening.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined One Year.

219.
EDWARD WICKHAM was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
MR. BALLANTINE conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM WALKER . I live in Upper Smith-street, Northampton-square. I have known the prisoner nine or ten months—he was introduced as Cap
tain Frew—he stated he was in the 35th Madras Infantry—some time ago he asked me to lend him 8l. on an £8 bill, for ten days—I consented to do so—he promised to pay it himself, if I would hold the bill till that time—I was to give Thomas Transfield, on account of that bill, 7l. 5s., and give the captain the other 15s.—Transfield introduced him to me as Captain Frew, and the captain promised to make me a present when the bill was paid—that bill was never paid—on the 6th of November he drew another bill—I produce that—it was drawn by the prisoner for 21l., and the former bill was cancelled—I advanced him 8l. 15s. more, besides the money for the first bill—this is for 21l., dated November 6th, signed "E. W. Frew"—he drew this bill in my presence—before it became due he brought this cheque—he then wished me to take my bill out, and give him the remainder—this is a cheque for 52l. 8s. 6d., signed by George Duncan, to Messrs. Coborn and Co., No. 4, Whitehall, dated from Liverpool, October 29th—I said I had not money enough in the house, and I would not do it till I had been to the bank—I went myself to the banker's with it, in the state in which it was—when I advanced the prisoner the 8l., I did it under the impression that he was a Captain Frew, of the East India Company's service—I always thought he was nothing else—I advanced the money to him, believing the promissory note was good and genuine—I have never received a farthing of the money I lent him, neither the first nor second.

Cross-examined by MR. PRICE. Q. How long have you known him? A. Nine or ten months—I first became acquainted with him by going to the Eagle tavern, City-road, to have a glass of gin and water, or a pint of beer—Transfield

introduced him to me there as Captain Frew—I never heard any other appellation at the tavern—I know that the captain lived at Windsor-ter
race, City-road, where the bill was made payable—I do not know whose house he lived at—I never inquired—I knew where he lived—all these representations occurred at the Eagle-tavern—I advanced my money con
siderably on the personal appearance and respectability of Captain Frew—I cannot tell the day that he first asked me for the 8l.—it was about two months ago, or perhaps not so much—it was about three weeks before the 6th of November I advanced 7l. 5s. to Transfield, and 15s. to him, by his order—I never had a written order to pay that 7l. 5s.—I had nothing but the bill—I did not tell Transfield that 15s. were deducted for the interest for the eight days—I told him I detained 15s. back for the captain—I did not keep 15s. back for interest—I paid 15s. to the captain the day after I paid the 7l. 5s. to Transfield, at three o'clock—I do not keep any books, nor does my wife—my wife receives the rents I live on, if I am not in the way—I have four houses, two at Camberwell, and two at Clerkenwell—I was not to receive any weekly payment for this money—the £8 bill was at ten days' date—he burnt it himself in my presence, at the time he gave me the £21 bill—it had become due about a day or two before—he did not draw it at the time I advanced Transfield the money—I paid him the next 8l. on the 6th of November, about ten days after I paid him the 15s.—only my wife and myself were present—I paid him the 8l. in the same place, and by myself—when he drew this bill he said, "I shall make you a handsome present"—he gave me the £21 bill—I do not know whether he meant to give me the 5l. or not—if he had paid the 2l. I should have returned him the change, but I should have taken the legal interest, and not more—that is not my usual way of doing business—I may charge more, but I considered the captain a safe man—I have never given any other money to persons in names that I knew were not theirs—I have never lent a gentleman money, and taken his account in a name that I knew was not his—I might not find it out.
COURT. Q. Do you mean to say that you have not done so? A. I have not—I have never lent money for the sake of usury.

Cross-examined by MR. PRICE. Q. You mean to swear now, on your oath that you never have lent any gentleman frequenting that tavern money in a name which you knew not to be his proper name? A. No, not that I know of—I do not know a gentleman named Reed, unless you mean Mr. Reed Baldwin—he is a singer—I do not know that Baldwin is a singing name—I do not know that his name is Reed, and not Baldwin—he has never told me that his real name was Reed, and not Baldwin—it is not correct if Mr. Baldwin should state that when he borrowed my money he told me his name was Reed, and I preferred to have it in the name of Baldwin—Baldwin introduced me to the prisoner as Captain Frew—he told me in the coffee-house that he was Captain Frew—Transfield also introduced him to me—they both did—he brought Captain Frew, and said, "This is Captain Frew, who wants to borrow some money of you"—that was some months after I knew Captain Frew—I cannot tell how long—he came himself, and asked me to lend him some money—I believe he came to me to borrow money for Tom Transfield, and not for himself, because Transfield had it from me—I believe he did not borrow the 8l. for himself, but he chose to give me his security—I heard that the money was wanted to pay Transfield's rent—I do not know why that rent was not paid—I understood the captain had it

back again from Transfield's father—I do not know how much—I believe it was 6l. 19s. 6d.—I do not think that it was in consequence of the cap
tain getting so large a portion of that back, that he wanted to borrow the second 8l. to pay him again—I do not know that the second 8l. was bor
rowed to repay the first—I believe the second 8l. was borrowed to repay Transfield—I suppose so—he did not tell me so—none of them told me—I believed it from report—from the captain himself—I have never heard from Transfield for what purpose it was borrowed—I do not know whose writ
ing this letter is—(looking at one)—the cheque was tendered to me by the captain before the bill became due, and that I refused to give cash for—I called at Windsor-terrace once, or not more than twice—I have never seen him or his wife go in there—I knew where he lodged, but he always re
presented himself as a single man—I know nothing of him, except this ca
sual acquaintance in the coffee-room.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Whether this money was lent for Transfield or for the prisoner's own purposes, have you received any of it since? A. None at all—I should not have lent the money without the bill given me by the prisoner—I believed the description of the prisoner upon the face of the note was a true description—I should not have lent a shilling of either of these sums if I had not believed that was correct.

WILLIAM ARCHER SHEE . I reside in Cavendish-square, and am in the Military Secretary's office in the East India House. No one of the prison
er's name appears to be in their service, supposing the lists to be correct, which we have every reason to imagine they are—I have made every pos
sible inquiry on this subject—there is a Captain Robert Frew on the re
tired list of the Madras army—there is no one with the initials "E. W. Frew."

Cross-examined. Q. You do not undertake to say there is no such person in the service? A. I can only give my testimony from the information I possess—when a gentleman gets leave to come home if he stops beyond five years, he is out of the service by Act of Parlia
ment, and he is not on the retired list—I have not inquired respecting the naval list—I have not searched the pension list—I have searched the re
tired list, which is the same as far as the names go.

RICHARD HAWKES (police-constable N 40.) On the 19th of November I went to No. 8, Windsor-terrace, City-road, to look for the person who calls himself Captain Frew—I saw a female at the door—I went up stairs in search of him, and on the third floor I found the prisoner—I told him he was wanted on a charge of obtaining money under false pretences—he asked to go to his apartments to change his dress, and he did so—as I was going up stairs I heard a noise in the third floor—I went up, and the prisoner had fallen down from a chair, in attempting to make his escape through a trap-door—he told me if he could have made his escape he would.

(Bill read)—"21l. 0s. 0d. Nov. 6, 1838. Ten days after date, I pro
mise to pay Mr. William Walker, or order, the sum of 21l. for value re
ceived. E. W. FREW, Capt. E. I. C. S. M. N. L"

THOMAS TRANSFIELD . I am a waiter at the Eagle tavern. I have known the prisoner ten or twelve months—he has frequented the house—on a late occasion I asked him to assist me in obtaining a loan, to oblige a part of my family, to save their goods from being seized—at that time Mr. Frew bad the note—I said, "I dare say Mr. Walker will advance the money for

him"—he said, "Very well"—I said that from knowing that Mr. Walker was in the habit of doing these things—I cannot read—Walker paid the money to me on the morning that he got the note from Mr. Frew—he paid me 7l. 5s.—he kept 15s. back for the interest—I think he said he bor
rowed it for fourteen days—I understood he would keep the bill himself—I took that money to my father—he did not pay the rent with it, on account of the landlord being out of town—I was given to understand that my father lent the money to the captain again—in a few days the captain ap
plied to Mr. Walker for more—my father was pressing for the money again.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What is the name of that person who has just left the court? A. He goes by the name of Baldwin—that is only his pro
fessional name—I was intimate with the prisoner no further than his using the coffee-room as a customer—I have been servant there about two years and three months—I asked him for the money as he was a customer—I could make more free with this gentleman than any other person—I can
not tell my reason—I was not on intimate terms with him—I was in the habit of seeing him out of doors from the bar to the saloon—I used not to walk about with him—I have met him when I have been going for pump water—I have seen him at his own house—I went with a letter once from Mrs. Rouse, my mistress—he was not intimate with my master and mis
tress, that I know of—I went to his house again, to take him a brace of birds that I bought for him, about six months ago—I did not make him a present of them—I did not think well of Mr. Walker, not so well as of the captain—I had no reason to think ill of him then—I believed him to be an honest man at the time I introduced my friend the captain to him—I know nothing further of him than borrowing money of him—Mr. Walker and I had had transactions together, two for myself and one for another person—I did introduce more than one to him—he behaved so well as to lend me money when I wanted it—I introduced another person to him to borrow money—as far as I know his conduct was all correct—I had no other reason than to believe him to be an honest, respectable man—7l. 5s. was paid by him to me at the Bird-cage, at the corner of Silver-street, Wood-street—I went to the landlord to pay the rent with it—my wife's father was with me—my landlord was not at home—he had been pressing for rent about a week or a fortnight before—the last time he applied was a week ago—I did not see him the day I had the money from Mr. Walker, but his clerk would not take it without I paid some taxes, which I would net—my wife's father went with me—the money went from me to my father-in-law's hands some three or four days after he told me he had given it back to Captain Frew—my father-in-law was present when I received the 7l. 5s.—I do not know that he had the 15s. for interest.
JURY. Q. Has that rent never been paid? A. It has, within the last week—my landlord was very pressing.

WILLIAM REED BALDWIN . My real name is William John Reed—it is a very general thing among theatricals to assume a name. I have recently had money transactions with Mr. Walker, who frequents the Eagle tavern—he was introduced to me as a person who lends money, by a person on the establishment—the original sum lent was 10l.—I was to repay by in
stalments of 7s. a week, to give a promissory note for 15l. 10s.—I told him when I went to sign the note my name was not Baldwin—it was only my
theatrical name—he said, "I know, but I know you by that name, and I shall take it."

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What are you? A. Chorus-master at the Eagle—I have known the prisoner some time—I never heard that he was appre
hended on a charge from Mr. Tennant—I heard it was Mr. Walker's charge—I have known the prisoner two years—I knew where he lived—I did not visit him—I never knew him in any regiment—I have heard say that he was in the East India Company's service, but whether he told me so I cannot tell.
MR. PRICE. The prisoner was always accosted and addressed by the name of Captain Frew? A. Yes, always.

LUKE WILLIAM WYMARK . I am a bookseller. I have known the pri
soner three years—he bore a most unexceptionable character.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did he lodge at your house? A. No, he re
sided at my house, and paid me 3s. a month in advance at first, but afterwards it was in arrears—he never went by the title of Captain Frew, but by the name of Wickham—he never represented that he was a captain in the East India Company's service—I took him to be a military man.
— KNOX. I live at No. 8, Windsor-terrace. The prisoner lodged with me for thirteen or fourteen months, till he was taken—he had a good character, and behaved like a gentleman.
MR. BALLANTINS. Q. Is Captain Frew married? A. I do not know any such man as Captain Frew—I never saw him to my knowledge.
JAMES WALMSLEY . I live in Tysoe-street, Wilmington-square. The prisoner lived with me for about a year and a half—he had a character of the strictest integrity.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. When did he leave you? A. About two years ago—he went by the name of Wickham.

GUILTY . Aged.—
Confined Twelve Months.
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

220.
THOMAS INGLETON was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of October, 1 coat, value 3l., the goods of
George Read.

GEORGE READ . I am ostler to Mr. Bottom, of Windmill-street, West
minster. On the 29th of October I was returning to town with a horse, and stopped at the Red Lion tap at Ilford—I gave my horse to the land
lady's son to hold—I had a coat attached to the saddle—I came out in a quarter of an hour, and it was gone—I have not seen it since, but I saw the prisoner with the horse coming up to the door—he had taken the horse from the boy that I gave it to—he gave the horse to the boy, and the boy ran into the house, and said my coat was gone—I am sure the prisoner is the man.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Were you sober? A. Yes—I had three cups of tea there—this was a chesnut-horse, rather high-cou
raged—he had thrown me off in going down to Chelmsford—the prisoner came into the tap-room, and sat down, and was taken into custody there—I asked him why he took the liberty of taking my horse from the door, and

told him my coat was gone—he asked if I had any mark on it—I said "Yes"—he said, "You have lost the coat, mark and all," and I had him taken—the little boy had got the horse outside while we were talking.

THOMAS HALES . I held the horse. I saw the coat on it—the pri
soner came out and asked me to let him have a ride—I told him he had better not, but he rode it five or six minutes—I ran by the side, and picked up a stick, and gave it to him—when I saw he was returning, I came back, and he said, "There is the horse," but the coat was gone then.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see how far he rode? A. About half a quarter of a mile—I did not go and look for the coat on the road—I am sure I had seen a coat there, it was tied with two pieces of rope—the horse was outside the door two or three minutes, without any one with it.

DANIEL KINGSNORTH . On the 29th of October, Read sent for me to take the prisoner—there was the rope, and the loop in front of the saddle had been cut—I took the prisoner—he swore he would not go—he was with several navigators in the house—I had a desperate struggle to get him out—I was thrown down, and was obliged to call other people.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you say one word before the Magistrate about his swearing be would not go, and about the navigators? A. Yes—I told the Magistrates all the particulars—I believe they took them down—he laid the coat was safe when be brought the horse back.

THOMAS HALES
re-examined. The horse had not been at the door alone before I held it—the prisoner came up, and rode away—the coat was safe then—I followed him, and came back two or three minutes before him.

MR. PAYNE. Q. Are you quite sure that you missed the coat at the time he first arrived, or afterwards? A. I missed—it. when he came up—he called me to come out—he came to the bar—he had left the house about a minute then.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Recorder.

221.
DAVID SMALL was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of No
vember, 3 half-crowns, 1 shilling, and 1 fourpenny-piece, the monies of
Joseph Stokes.

JOSEPH STOKES . I live in Woolwich, and am in the Royal Artillery. On Saturday, the 1st of November, I placed my jacket on the prisoner's bed, which joins mine, while I made my own bed—it was about a quarter before eight o'clock in the evening—I left my jacket there, when I got into bed—I had in it three half-crowns, one shilling, and one fourpenny-piece, in a wash-leather purse—I missed it the following morning, about half-past six o'clock—twelve or fourteen persons slept in the same room—they would have an opportunity of seeing where I placed my jacket—I asked Mills to look for my jacket, after I got to bed, and then Small flung it on my bed, off his own bed—Mills doubled it up, and put it on the top of the saddle-bags—I have never seen the purse since—it could not have escaped from the jacket when it was thrown—it was thrown but a little way, and if it had

I should have seen it in the morning—it was about five minutes past eight o'clock at night when Small threw it to me—I did not miss the money till half-past six o'clock in the morning—my jacket was on the saddle-bag, at the head of my own bed—there was nothing to prevent any one else getting at it in the night—I was a little the worse for liquor the overnight, but was capable of doing my duty—I did not mention to the prisoner my sus
picions till the next morning, after the sergeant-major had told him of it—his showing some money to the men in the room, the night he took it, gave us suspicion.

DAVID MILLS . I am a gunner in the Royal Artillery. On the 1st of November I left the stables about eight o'clock in the evening, and went to bed—I saw Small sitting on the outside of his bed, not in bed—he had his jacket off as he came from the stable—the prosecutor was sitting on his bed—he got up, and came towards the fire, with his jacket in his hand, then he went back to his bed, with the jacket, and laid it somewhere—I do not know where—my bed was next to Small's bed, and Stokes called me to get his jacket for him—I went to the fire to look for it, and could not find it—I was coming back to tell him, and I saw the prisoner, with the jacket in his hand, and his right-hand was in the pocket—I saw the buttons on the sleeve of the jacket—I was coming to the prosecutor, and Small called out, "Here is your jacket, Stokes," he then threw it on his bed and folded it up—I saw Small stoop and take up his own jacket, and put his hand to the pocket of his own jacket, and I heard something jingle as it was falling in, which I thought was money—I got up about a quarter past six o'clock in the morning.

Prisoner. Q. Where were you? A. I was coming to tell Stokes I did not see his jacket by the fire—I saw you sitting on the bed, and the jacket was on your knee at the time—I think there were two candles burning on the table.

TIMOTHY POOLE . I am a driver in the Royal Horse Artillery. I went to these quarters about eight o'clock—I saw the prisoner there—I saw him take 1s. 6d. in silver, and 7 1/2 d. in copper out of his own jacket-pocket, before he pulled it off—he put it into his pocket again, and then he west to his bed—in about twenty minutes after he called me to his bed-side, and showed me three half-crowns, one shilling, one fourpenny-piece, and some halfpence, and said it was all his own—there were two beds between his and mine—Stokes's bed was not on the same side—I did not see any purse.

GEORGE PARRY . I am a gunner in the Royal Artillery. I went into the room where the prisoner and the prosecutor slept about ten minutes past eight o'clock—the prisoner had three half-crowns, and 1s. 3d.—he said, "Parry, I will give you this money to take care of till the morning, as I don't know who sleeps beside me," and he gave it me—I have got that money.

Prisoner. I gave him my own money—I enlisted for a recruit, and I got the money of the quarter-master—that they all knew. Witness. He had been about a month in the regiment—he would receive ten shillings, and he had paid the quarter-master half-a-crown.

Prisoner. I got this money, and came home after I had done drill—I laid my jacket on the bed—it was thrown off, and the money fell out—I picked it up, and put it into my own pocket—it was my own money. Wit
ness. I did not know him till he enlisted, which is about a month ago—the
prisoner's jacket was not searched—the following morning he was taken off at the guard-room—I was not the worse for liquor.

TIMOTHY POOLE
re-examined. I saw him with a fourpenny-piece—I was not the worse for liquor.
Prisoner. Mills did not say any thing that night, hut the next day he said he saw my hand in the pocket.

DAVID MILLS
re-examined. I thought I could put more dependence in my comrade than to think he would do that—I did not think he Was taking my money—I heard the money ring, but I did not like to interfere with the man—I did not suppose that he had taken any money till I heard it ring—I did not know whether Stokes had money.
JURY. Q. Bid you see a purse? A. No—the prisoner was not charged with this till a quarter past seven o'clock in the morning, after he had been to the stable.
Prisoner. I did not carry any jacket with me to the stable—I could not have had it in my pocket. Witness. You would have pockets in your trowsers too.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Judgment Respited.

222.
ROBERT AMBROSE was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of November, 6lbs. weight of chain, value 1l., the goods of
Charles Yewan, his master.

CHARLES YEWAN . I am a stone-mason, and live at Parson's-hill, Wool
wich. I lost a sling-chain, which was safe on my premises on the 8th of November—the prisoner was in my employ as a labourer—I did not miss it till I received information, and found it at the constable's house.

LEWIS EVANS . I am a private in the Royal Marines. On the 10th of November I went to an alley at the back of Mr. Yewan's premises, and saw the prisoner come into the alley, stop there about a minute, and then break into Mr. Yewan's premises by getting through a hole in the railing—soon after I heard the rattling of a chain, and he crept out with the chain—I fol
lowed him to another street, where he offered it for sale, but the man would not buy it—I went and inquired for a constable, and while I went to the constable's house he threw the chain down—I ran after him, but lost him—this was on Saturday—I saw him again on Monday, working on the road—I did not know him before, but I am sure he is the person.

JUDITH CAMPION . I am the wife of William Campion, a constable. On Saturday, the 10th Nov., Mr. Evans came to my husband's shop-door, and asked for a constable—I heard a chain drop—I went out, picked it up, and took it into my house—Mr. Yewan afterwards claimed it.
WILLIAM CAMPION . I am a constable of Woolwich. I received the sling-chain from my wife—I took the prisoner on the Monday—he said he had offered it for sale.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. Evans asked me to sell his great coat, and to sell the chain—he then said he would go and take me to the constable, unless I gave him 2s. or 3s., and I gave him 1s.—he and another marine took money to let me go.

LEWIS EVANS
re-examined. He never gave me any money—I never spoke to him at all till he was in custody at the station-house—I had no acquaintance with him at all—I tried to apprehend him, but he ran down a dark alley—there was another marine there, but he says he did not see him—I
heard him throw the chain down as J was at the constable's door—I did not stop him, not thinking it proper for me to take him—when he saw me speak to the constable's wife he threw the chain down.

GUILTY . Aged 18.*—
Transported for Seven Years.

223.
FRANCES COBARN was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of November, 1 watch, value 2l.; 1 watch-guard, value 6d.; 1 watch-chain, value 6d.; 1 watch-key, value 1d.; 1 seal, value 2s.; 1 sovereign; and 6 shillings; the goods and monies of
Charles Weightman, from his person.

CHARLES WEIGHTMAN . I am servant to Lieutenant Saville, of the Royal Artillery; I am a private. On the 16th of November my master sent me to Woolwich—I was to return next morning—I got up between four and five o'clock on the 17th, and went to the Coach and Horses public-house, to get a pint of beer and a glass of gin, about half-past five o'clock—the pri
soner came in while I was there, with another young woman, and two men, dressed as sailors—they had something to drink—I got into conversation with the sailors—they asked me to drink at different times, and I became quite insensible by drinking with them—when I awoke I found myself is another public-house, the Duke on Horseback, in a room on the ground-floor—my watch, seal, and guard, a sovereign, and 5s. or 6s. were gone—this is the watch I lost—it is my property—(looking at it.)

MARY MARQUIS . I am single, and live in High-street, Woolwich. I went to the Coach and Horses on the morning in question—I saw the prosecutor there drunk—I remember the prisoner coming in with others—they drank together, and the prisoner left the house with the prosecutor, to go home together—I afterwards saw them at the Duke on Horseback—they had a quartern of rum there, and I partook of some there—the prosecutor pro
duced a sovereign, and told me to pay for the rum—he laid it down, and before I could get hold of it, the prisoner took it up—she put it down at the bar to pay, and took the change herself—the prosecutor fell asleep there, and the prisoner tried to awake him—she took the guard off his neck, with the watch to it, and took it to the bar, to be taken care off till the man awoke—she was gone when he awoke—she did not give the prosecutor his change—he was in the parlour.

SUSAN FOX . I was at the Coach and Horses, and saw the prisoner come in, with another young woman and two men—she asked the prosecutor to drink—I afterwards went to the Duke on Horseback, and saw them there—they had more liquor there—Weightman threw a sovereign down on the table to pay for the rum—the prisoner took it up to the bar, changed it, and put the change in her glove—I then went out with her—she had a basket in her hand—I saw nothing of the watch—I was not noticing any thing at the time—she asked me to go down the street—I said I had no shawl on my neck—she gave me a shilling, which I gave her back—she bought me a shawl in the street, and asked me to go back—Mr. Campion came, and took the watch out of her hand at his own door as we passed—she must have got it away from the bar, but I had not seen her do it—she had money of her own in the basket—I do not know whether the shawl was paid for with her own money or the prosecutor's.

CHARLES HART . I am son to Mr. Hart, who keeps the Duke on Horse
back—the prisoner brought me a watch, and told me to take care of it, saying it belonged to the man in the parlour—she came back afterwards,

and said the man was making a noise about it—I gave it to her, and she took it into the parlour, and then came out again—I found the prosecutor sleep in the room—the prisoner was also tipsy—15d. was taken out of the sovereign for liquor.

WIILIAM CAMPION . I am a constable of Woolwich. On Saturday morning, the 17th of November, I went to find the prisoner, and met her, in company with two or three females, about half-past ten o'clock, about half a mile from The Duke on Horseback—I heard her say before I took her, that she should pull out her watch and see what o'clock it was—one of the women said, "You had better not, for fear you should break it"—I went up, and took it from her bosom—I found 10s. 8d. on her—I charged her with stealing the watch—she said, "Oh, let me see the man, I think I can make it right with him"—that she could make the sovereign up with the man, if she could see him—she had been drinking the knew what she was saying.

Prisoner's Defence. I left the young man asleep in the house—he threw the sovereign down on the table, and I paid for a quartern of rum at the bar—the young man asked me to take care of his watch and money for hint—I went out to take a walk, and took the watch to the bar for them to take care of—when I returned he was asleep—I could not awake him to give him the watch, and we went out as far as the Hampshire Hog to get some chops—in going flown the town, passing Mr. Campion's, I said, "We will go back to see if the young man is awake, and give him his watch"—Cam
pion. then came out—they fetched the young man out, and he said he was very sorry, he had been asleep, and did not know what had passed.

WILLIAM CAMPION
re-examined. She might have gone to The Duke on Horseback the way she was going, but it was very much out of her way from where she described she had been—I found no more money on her—after I took her she said she was going to take it back.

CHARLES HART
re-examined. I returned her the watch almost directly after she brought it—I believe it was about nine o'clock—I did pot see her afterwards till she was apprehended—our waiter went in and awoke the prosecutor.

CHARLES WEIGH THAN
re-examined. I was not aware the prisoner had got the watch, only from information the people in the house gave me—I was not told that Hart had got it—a man who cleaned up the room told me he believed a woman had gone out with it.

SUSAN FOX
re-examined. The prisoner said something about going back to The Duke on Horseback, but Mr. Campion got up, and I could not hear what she said.
NOT GUILTY .

224.
SAMUEL BROOKS was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of No
vember, three shirts, value 6s.; 1 jacket, value 4s.; and 1 pair of breeches, value 5s.; the goods of
Lewis Davis, his master.

LEWIS DAVIS . I am a wholesale clothier, and live at Green's-end, Woolwich. The prisoner was four years in my service—I lost a quantity of articles, which I found in pledge—I employed a constable to search—(looking at a note)—the pawnbroker showed me this note—it is the pri
soner's writing—when I supposed the prisoner was the thief I sent for him, and said to him, "I have missed a great quantity of these shirts; do you know any thing about it?"—he said, "No"—I said, "I am quite certain

there must be some unfair play here; have you had any one at the work-shop to-day who is likely to have taken any away?"—he said, "No"—I said, "What quantity of them have you*"—he said, "Not any"—I asked where he lived—he told me—I said, "I shall search, for I think you must know something of them"—he said he lived in Bray's-buildings—I said, "You have a lodging at Delagar's, the publican"—I called the office; and sent him with the prisoner to search the place.

WILLIAM THOMAS CHITTENDEN . I am a constable of Woolwich. On the 17th of November I went with Mr. Davis to the Earl of Chatham public-house, and was shown a room there—I found a bundle containing two shirts—the prisoner was sent for to—I opened the bundle, and took out the shirts—the prisoner produced the key of another box in the room—I found there another shirt, and detained him—I found on him a duplicate for a jacket and breeches.

THOMAS PACY BIRT . I am a pawnbroker, in Hare-street, Woolwich. I produce a jacket and breeches—I do not know who they were pawned by, but I gave the party this duplicate—this note was left with the things—I did not know the prisoner was constantly in the prosecutor's employ—I knew he was a tailor.
(Note read.)—"Sir, please to lend on this fisher boy's suit 6s. "SAMUEL BROOKS."

LEWIS DAVIS
re-examined. These articles are mine—they are not made for sale, but for the Navy.

Prisoner's Defence. I took them home to get a stain out of the one found in my box—the others I took home to get altered, which it was my duty to do—I had five suits of the clothes, and did pledge them, as I wanted money—I put the shirts on a chair when I took them home—the one stained was left with my wife to get the stain out, and I placed it in my box—the other two remained loose in the room for fire days—I did not secrete them—I was going to give them to a person to alter.

LEWIS DAVIS
re-examined. These are navy shirts—it was the prisoner's duty to receive them when made, and send a cheque round for payment——those which are not made right he was empowered to get altered—not to take to his private lodging, but to give them to work-people who came to the shop—his wife worked for us.
GUILTY of stealing the jacket and breeches.—Aged 50.
Confined Three Months.

225.
MARY LOVELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of Novem
ber, 2 pairs of pattens, value 1s. 10d., the goods of
James Gilham.

WILLIAM GILHAM . I am the son of James Gilham, a shoemaker in Nelson-street, Greenwich. On the 1st of November, while I was attend
ing to a customer, I received information which induced me to go towards the hospital—I overtook the prisoner, and asked what she had in her basket—she made no reply—I saw through the top of the basket two pain of pattens—I told her she had stolen them from the door—she said she had bought them of a man in the market-place—they were my pattens, and had hung by the side of the doorway outside—I had seen them five minutes before.

MART POWELL . I am servant to Mr. Gilham. I was in the kitchen on the 1st of November, and saw the prisoner take the pattens off the hooks and put them into her basket—I told my master, he followed and took her.
DANIEL RIERDON (police-constable R 207.) I went in search of the
prisoner, and found her in the park—I tool her to Mr. Gilham, who gave me two pairs of pattens.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I bought them of a man in the market-place, for 6d.

GUILTY . Aged 38.—
Confined One Month.

226.
EDWARD DONALD was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of Octo
ber, 1 coat, value 10s., and 1 pair of gloves, value 1s., the goods of
John Hop-wood.

JOHN HOPWOOD . I am porter to Mr. Taylor, an upholsterer in Dover-road. On the 26th of October, in the afternoon, I hung my coat across the horse in my master's van—I was taking a sofa into Mr. Holt's house, and when I came out my coat was gone off the horse—the gloves were in the pocket.

CHARLES NICHOLLS (police-constable R 164.) On the 26th of October I was on duty about half-past six o'clock, and was informed that a coat was concealed under some leaves on the top of, Croom's-hill—I concealed myself in a garden, and about twenty minutes before eight o'clock the prisoner came in company with another one—he came direct to the spot, turned the leaves off, laid hold of the coat, and threw it over his arm—I jumped out and collared him, and the moment I collared him a pair of high shoes fell from him—I asked how he knew the coat was there—he said he did not know it was there, he saw it as he was passing, but he could not have seen it, it was quite covered with leaves—I took up the shoes—the other man made his escape—there was a donkey just by.

Prisoner. I was taken a quarter of an hour before the boots were produced—I know nothing of it whatever—I was walking across the park, there was a donkey before me and a young man—he said, "Look at that donkey"—I passed it, and it stumbled over the coat and turned the tail up—the constable came up and charged me with stealing it—he went there afterwards and found the boots.

Witness. The donkey did not disturb the leaves—I was concealed there an hour before he came—there was six inches of leaves over the coat, and it was three yards out of the path—the donkey did not tread near the leaves.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY .—Aged 14.

227.
EDWARD DONALD
was again indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of October, 2 pairs of shoes, value 16s.; and 1 shoe, value 2s.; the goods of
William Newsom.

WILLIAM NEWSOM . I lost some shoes and boots out of my shop on the 26th of October, about half-past seven o'clock—my shop is about a quarter of a mile from Croom's-hill—I ran down the street on missing them, and went to the station-house—somebody must have got into my shop to get them—I was in the shop—they must have opened the door and crawled in.

CHARLES NICHOLLS (police-constable R 164.) I saw the prisoner near the spot where the coat was concealed, about half-past seven o'clock or twenty minutes to eight—I jumped up and laid hold of him, and a pair of high shoes fell from him—I saw his companion go twenty or thirty yards from the spot, and go round the corner of a wall and stoop—I afterwards received information that these shoes were stolen—the prisoner denied that the shoes fell from him, but I am certain they did—I found the others be
hind the wall where I saw his companion stoop.
Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing of the slides—he took me ten minutes before he found them—he went and kicked up the leaves with his foot, and said I had dropped them.
Witness. No, I found them directly I laid hold of him—I kicked about to see if there was any thing else—I afterwards took a lantern, and found the rest where his companion had stooped.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY .* Aged 14.—
Transported for Seven Years to the Juvenile Prison.
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

228.
MICHAEL DYER was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of No-vember, 1 chisel, value 1s.; 1 oil-stone, value 1s.; 1 pair of compasses, value 6d.; 1 square, value 1s.; and 1 rule, value 1s.; the goods of
Wil
liam Downard; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Three Months.

229.
RICHARD FOWLER and
GEORGE HEATH were indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of November, 1 watch, value 2l. 10s.; 2 seals, value 16s.; 1 watch-key, value 3s.; and 1 watch-chain, value 6d.; the goods of
Thomas Weaver, from his person.

THOMAS WEAVER . I live in Hogg-lane, Woolwich, and am a shoe
maker. On the 1st of November I was at the Duke public-house, sitting by the fire with my gin-and-water—I got up, and some one took my place—I asked him to move—he struck me, and there was a row—the two prisoners were there—I lost my watch—I asked the landlord if he would lock the door—he said he would not—several more were sitting near me—Fowler was my second when I fought—he came and assisted me—I did not ask him to come—it was not with my consent—he held me round the waist, and I felt him feeling for my watch—Heath was in the room, but I did not see him do any thing—this is my watch—(looking at it.)

Fowler. Q. When you felt my hand at your watch, why did you not accuse me of it? A. I did not feel you take it—I went to the bar after it—I said I had lost my handkerchief, and afterwards found it in my pocket.

Fowler. Q. You went out and accused a female of taking your watch, and came back—I still remained at the bar, and had a pint of half-and-half—why did you not have me taken then?—bow can you say it was my hand against your watch, when there were from twenty-five to thirty people—did you see any marks on my hand? Witness. I did not see any marks.
Heath. Q. Can you tell how far I was off you? A. About two yards, I should think.

SARAH BUTCHER . I came out of the Duke public-house on that night—Heath came out, and went home with me—he said, "I have got something in my pocket that I gave 1l. 1s. for, you must pawn it to
morrow morning for 8s., keep 2s. for yourself, and give me the remainder—that was this key and seal—I went and gave them to the watchman.
Heath. Q. Did I ever say I bought it? A. Yes—I never saw you with any person—you came up to me when I was crossing the road.

CHARLES STEWART WARDEN . On the 2nd of November I went to the Earl Grey beer-shop, and I saw Fowler asleep—I left him, and from informa
tion

I went across the road, and there saw Conner, who is not in custody—I went to the Earl Grey again, aroused Fowler, and told him he was suspected of having stolen a watch—he said he had done no such thing, but because he was there he must be suspected—I found a half-crown and two shillings in his pocket—I then took him into custody with Conner, in the van to Woolwich—I found on Conner a duplicate of the watch—when they got off the van, Fowler squared up at me—Conner called out to Fowler to stick up to me, and Conner made his escape.
Fowler. Q. Did you not ask Conner whether it was his witch, and he said yes? A. I asked if it related to his property, and he said yes.
JOSEPH CUNNINGHAM . I am shopman to a pawnbroker at Deptford. Conner pawned this watch with me.
Fowler. Q. What time was it? A. Between half-past eight and nine o'clock—I did not see you there.

WILLIAM GREEN . I am a constable. Between one and two o'clock on the morning of Friday, Butcher offered me the key and seals—I went to her house and took the prisoner Heath, but previously when I was called into the house, I saw Fowler with his arms round the prosecutor, and Heath after that accused Butcher of taking the witch.

Fowler. Q. Did you hear that the watch was lost when you saw me in the house? A. No—I did not come into the parlour—the landlord had settled it himself—he was in before me—I did not see you afterwards—I had no business to shut the doors and search every person there—I came to quiet the row, and the landlord bad quieted it before I got to the door of the room.
Heath. You say that I ran away? Witness. No—I say you accused the girl of robbing the man of the watch—I took the girl away, and when I came back you were gone.

Fowler. He says he did not see me afterwards, and he states in the depositions that he saw me go through the gardens at half-past two o'clock in the morning with Conner. Witness. No—I saw Conner go through the garden at two o'clock in the morning, and another man, who, I believe, was Fowler—the row was between twelve and one o'clock.

Fowler's Defence. I went into this house about eleven o'clock, and Conner was there—I sat down, and had a pint of porter: lifter that Conner said, "We will have a pot between us"—we did to—I saw the prosecutor get up to get a glass of gin-and-water from the mantel-shelf—there, was a quarrel about a chair, and the prosecutor knocked a man down—I picked him up;—after that he went to the bar, and said he had lost his watch—the next morning I went to Greenwich and saw Conner come out of a public-house—we went on and went to another public-house—he said, "Stop there till I come back," which I did, and fell asleep till the officer came and apprehended me.
Heath's Defence. I was not in the house above half an hour, and I was awoke up—I picked up the seals in the tap-room, but I did not take them from the man's person.

JURY to THOMAS WEAVER. Q. Were the seals and key on the ring? A. Yes, and the ring was broken, I dare say—I have not seen it since—it was all together when I lost it—I have got one of the seals myself—the other seal and key the woman has produced.

230.
GEORGE WILSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of November, 8 yards of carpeting, value 30s., the goods of
Robert Lucas Jeeves and another.

ROBERT LUCAS JEEVES . I am in partnership with James Cobbett, a floor-cloth and carpet-manufacturer at Greenwich. On the 20th of No
vember I was returning in my cart from Blackheath, and within three or four doors from my house, I saw a boy with this carpet on his shoulders—I suspected it was wrong from the pattern being reversed—in coming to my shop a boy touched his hat, and asked if I wanted an errand-boy—, but I would not be diverted from the carpet—I saw the boy who had it, give it to the prisoner about twenty yards off—I called to a person to take care of my horse and cart, and when I went round the way they went, I could see neither the carpet nor the prisoner, nor the boys—but in a to
bacconist's shop I saw the prisoner—I wished to secure the boys—I saw them running towards Greenwich,—I thought I should lose the prisoner—I came back and he was gone from the shop—a witness came up and gave me information—this is the carpet—the prisoner had put it down it a tailor's shop.

JAMES SHEPHERD . I was looking out of my master's window—I saw a man come up with some carpet and place it at the door—the prisoner answers the description of the man, but I had such a slight glance of him that I cannot swear to him.

CHARLES PATNE . I live at Deptford-bridge. At half-past eleven o'clock, I was opposite the prosecutor's shop, and saw two boys—one first came out with this carpet on his shoulder—the other came out and met the prosecutor—he put his hand to his hat and said, "Do you want a shop-boy?"—I saw the boy that took the carpet give it to the prisoner who was waiting as if for the boys, and then I saw him with it.
Prisoner. Q. Did you lose sight of me? A. Yes, when you turned into the tobacco-shop—I saw you come out again—you had not the carpet then.
COURT. Q. Are you sure he is the person that had the carpet and took it from the boys? A. Yes, I did not see him put it down, but it was at a tailor's shop.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined One Year.

231.
WILLIAM HILL was Indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of No
vember, 2 pairs of clogs, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
James Towers; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

EDWARD GEORGE SMITH . I have the management of Mr. James Towers's boot and shoe-warehouse, in London-street, Greenwich. About seven o'clock, on the 16th of November, the prisoner was brought to my shop, with two pairs of clogs, which I believe are my master's—I have missed two pairs—these are them—they have no mark on them.

JOHN EVANS (police-constable R 190.) About seven o'clock that even
ing, I was on duty in London-street, and saw the prisoner walk from the prosecutor's shop—I stopped him and found this property under his arm—he was between six and eight yards from the shop when I took him.
THOMAS TAYLOR (police-constable T 26.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the man that was tried and convicted.

Prisoner's Defence. I came out of the House of Correction in August—I found my character lost, and I was compelled to go and commit the crime over again—I could not get work—I came from Birmingham, and would return there again if I could—I have applied to the parish, and they would not relieve me.

GUILTY . Aged 46.—
Confined Two Days.

232.
ELIZABETH REYNOLDS was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of November, 14oz. weight of wax, value 6d.; 1 watch-guard, value 2s.; 2 pairs of scissors, value 4s.; 1 purse, value 7s.; 1 brash, value 9d.; I pencil-case, value 4d.; and 1 knife, value 2d.; the goods of
William Sul
man, her master.

JANE SULMAN . I am the wife of William Sulman, a toy-dealer, in Stockwell-street, Greenwich. The prisoner was my servant—I went to her box and found some things, but nearly all were returned on the Thurs
day—here are two pairs of scissors, a brooch, a purse, a nail-brush, and flannel, which were in her box—she said her mother had given them to her—I asked her to fetch her mother—she said she could not—and then I told her to leave and send her mother for her wages.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. She returned to you and then left on account of illness? A. She was to come back when she got better—I believe she took them out of folly—she gave some of them to some persons—I was willing to take her back, but her father prosecuted her—I did not.
ELIZABETH READING being called, did not answer.

CHARLES NICHOLLS . I am a police-man. I went to the prisoner's father's house, and took her—I found in her pocket a knife, a purse, and thimble——the knife was identified by the prosecutrix—the prisoner's father sent me to take her.
NOT GUILTY .

233.
RICHARD TERRY and
JOSEPH TERRY were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of November, 4 decanters, value 1l. 5s. the goods of
Joseph Burnby.

JOSEPH TERRY pleaded
Guilty*—Aged 18.

JOSEPH BURNBY . I live at High-street, Deptford, and am a glass-dealer. At a quarter before twelve o'clock on the morning of the 7th of November, I was coming from the back premises and saw the two prison
ers at the counter—I called to them and they immediately left the shop—I followed them—I missed four decanters—one was left on the board outside the door, and Joseph Terry dropped two of them on my following him.
BENJAMIN LOVELL . I am a police-man. I found this one decanter at the house of Joseph Terry, in about a quarter of an hour.
Joseph Terry. It was found at home, but I did not put it there nor take it.

GUILTY .* Aged 13.—Both
Transported for Seven Years.

234.
HARRIET ALLENDER was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of November, 1 vice, value 8s., the goods of
Frederick Bennik.
FREDERICK BENNIK . I am a Greenwich pensioner. On the 17th of
November I lost this vice—(looking at it.)—the prisoner was a lodger at our house, but left two or three days after—I did not lend it to her—it was fixed in the wash-house.
Prisoner's Defence. The woman you kept gave it to me to sell for old iron—she knew I sold it for 5 1/2 d., as I had no victuals to eat all day.
ELIZABETH KIER . I am the wife of John Kier. I bought the vice of the prisoner for 5 1/2 d. as old iron.
NOT GUILTY .

235.
WILLIAM BROWN was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of October, 1 pair of shoes, value 7s., the goods of
George Carpenter and another; and
HENRY BURT
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

GEORGE CARPENTER . I am in partnership with Samuel Carpenter, a boot and shoemaker, in London-street, Greenwich. I was in the parlour on the 26th of October—I turned and saw Brown in the shop—I asked him what he wanted—he said he had done mischief, he had strewed some papers on the floor—he asked if I wanted any pattens or clogs—I said, no—as soon as he had left, I missed a pair of shoes—I went to the end of the street, and brought him back—I asked him if he knew any thing of the shoes—he said no, but that he saw a lad leave the shop with a bag on his back—I asked if he should know the lad—he said, yes—I took him to several places about the town, but could not find the lad—I let him go, but still followed him, and saw him go to the other prisoner—they went across the Creek bridge—each of them was carrying a bag—they saw me, and dropped their bags—I caught Brown and took him to Dept
ford—Burt's bag contained three pairs of shoes, one of which belonged to me—Burt was taken afterwards.
Brown. I had nothing at all in my Bag. Witness. Burt had not been in my shop that day—he could not have taken them.
Brown. I saw this boy—we went on towards London, and a man came and gave him the bag.
(Burt received a good character.)

BROWN—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

BURT—
GUILTY .
Aged 16.
Confined Three Months.

236.
JOHN JAMES was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of November, 1 plane, value 4s.; 1 stock, value 12s.; 2 centre-bits, value 1s.; and 1 gimlet, value 4d.; the goods of
Robert Fitch; and that he had been before convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Transported for Seven Years.

237.
HARRIET MANN was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of Oc
tober, 1 bolster, value 4s.; 1 pillow, value 2s.; 1 cup, value 1d.; 1 saucer value 1d.; 1 pillow-case, value 6d.; 1 knife, value 3d.; 1 tumbler, value 1s. 3d.; and 1 printed book, value 3d.; the goods of
George Samuel Cole; and that she had been before convicted of felony.
GEORGE SAMUEL COLE . I am a fruiterer, and live in Trafalgar-road, Greenwich. The prisoner came to my house on the 9th of October, and hired a furnished room—she came in on the 11th and 12th, and was

there about four days, and four nights on and off—she went without notice—I then went into the room, and missed all these things—no other person had an opportunity of taking them—I have other lodgers who have been with me six months.
Prisoner. Other people had access to the room. Witness. Yes, they had.
GEORGE ROBINSON . I am a marine store dealer in the Old Woolwich-road. I produce a cup and saucer, a book and knife—I bought them of the prisoner on the 12th and 14th of October.
Prisoner. I asked you if you knew Mr. Cole, and you said yes—I sold them before I went to Mr. Cole. Witness. You asked me if I knew Mr. Cole, and I told you I did.
CHARLES REEVE . I am an apprentice to Mr. Stock, a pawnbroker. I have a sheet pawned on the 12th of October, but not by the prisoner—this is the duplicate of it.
ROBERT DUNN . I am a police-sergeant. I searched the prisoner's room, and found a corresponding duplicate to this shirt;, also a shirt and pillow pawned at Dawson's.
JOHN DAWSON . I am a pawnbroker. I have a sheet and pillow—this is the duplicate.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. The room was open to any one—I had been out four days previous to the things being missed—the other things I sold be
fore I went there—they were my own.

JAMES WILDS . I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former convic
tion from Mr. Clark's office—(read.)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Transported for Seven Years.

238.
DAVID WHITE was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of Oc
tober, 1 watch, value 2l. 10s.; 1 watch-key, value 2d.; and 1 seal, value 2d.; the goods of
George Blackman.

GEORGE BLACKMAN . I am a bugleman in the first battalion of the rifle brigade. I had a watch and key safe on the 16th of October—I had it in my pocket at the Two Brewers at Maid stone, at a quarter before ten o'clock at night—I got drunk, but was sober enough to know that I had it then—I went to sleep at the Two Brewers—I awoke about eleven o'clock, my watch, purse, and other things were gone—my watch had been in my pocket—this is my watch and key—(looking at them.)

SAMUEL MARTIN . I am a sawyer, living in Union-street, Maidstone. I have a brother in the rifle brigade—I went into the Two Brewers that night—the prisoner and another came in—I know the prisoner—he was in there drinking—they were talking one to another—I asked him for a piece of tobacco—he gave it to me, and I fell asleep—when I awoke he was gone, and the prosecutor's watch was lost.

WILLIAM PHIPPS . I am a police-inspector. On the 18th of October I was on duty in Charlton fair—I took the prisoner and two others, and found on him this watch and key—I asked if it was his—he said yes, he had had it eight or ten years—that it was given him by his father, and he got it repaired at Woolwich, four or five months back.
GUILTY . Aged 28.

239.
DAVID WHITE
was again indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of October, 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of
George Alderson, from his person.

GEORGE ALDERSON . I am an engineer in a steam-boat. On the 18th of October I was at Charlton fair, in one of the booths—I had a handker
chief—I missed it—I had seen it five minutes before—this is my handker
chief, it has my initials on it—(looking at it.)

WILLIAM PHIPPS . I am a police inspector. I took the prisoner at Chalton Fair, and found four handkerchiefs on him—this was one, also a purse, a flash note for 5l., a pair of scissors, a knife, tobacco-box, and key.

GUILTY .* Aged 28.—
Transported for Ten Years.

240.
SAMUEL POLLARD was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of November, 1 bag, value 1d.; 1 half-crown, 6 shillings, and 1 sixpence; the goods and monies of
John Tick.

JOHN TICK . I am a fishmonger, living at Greenwich. On the 3rd of November I saw the prisoner near my stall, in Beer-lane, Greenwich—I sent him on errands—he behaved with the greatest propriety from Friday till Saturday—on Sunday, when I came home to dinner my wife asked me if I had taken a bag out of the drawer containing 9s.—I said no—I then sent for the prisoner—he came, and I accused him of it—he said he did not touch it—he said, "Why should I rob you, when you behaved so well to me?"—I then put it into the policeman's hands, and he asked him why he should rob this poor man, after he behaved so well to him—he asked him several questions, and then the prisoner got up, went to the balustrade of the square, and pulled out a purse containing 5s., which was part of my money.
WILLIAM SUTTLE . I was present when the prisoner went for this money—he gave it into my hand.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Four Days.
(The prosecutor promised to take him into his employ again.)

241.
JAMES RUSSELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of November, 1 pair of trowsers, value 5s., the goods of
William Oliver.

WILLIAM OLIVER . I am servant to James Cornish, of Plumstead. On Saturday night I purchased a pair of trowsers in the Kent-road—I put them into a sack, on the wagon which the prisoner was driving for me—he went on to Blackheath, and said, "Bill, your trowsers are lost, some one has taken them"—I said, "You must know something about it"—he denied it—I said there had been nobody in the wagon but our two selves—the policeman came up, and the prisoner began to cry—the officer pulled the trowsers out from under his waistcoat—the prisoner said, "You won't hurt me."
URIAH EDEN (police-constable R 81.) I pulled the trowsers from under the prisoner's waistcoat, and took him in charge.
GUILTY . Aged 23.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.
Confined One Month.
Before Mr. Recorder.

242.
JOHN HUNT was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of No
vember, two dead fowls, value 4s., the goods of
Erasmus Mawby; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Seven Days.

243.
JAMES HOLT was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of No
vember, 1 mare, price 26l., the property of
Thomas Hoath.

THOMAS HOATH . I am a market-gardener, and live at Merton, in Surrey. On the morning of the 5th of November I gave directions to Hughes, my man, to take my chesnut mare to a meadow belonging to Mr. Milton—I missed it the same evening—she had a short tail, and had a white mark on the face—she was about five years old—I saw her again nine days after I think, in possession of West, at Buntingford, in Hert
fordshire.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. I believe she was placed in a field by the high-road? A. Yes—I believe the gate was left open by some
body.
CHARLES HUGHES . I put the mare in the field at Merton, on the 5th of November, and shut the gate when I left it—I went there again at five o'clock in the afternoon, and it was gone.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you fastened the gate, or locked it? A. I did not lock it—I did not see the mare that day afterwards—the gate does not open on the road—it is a side gate—there was nothing to prevent the animal coming into the road if the gate was open.

GEORGE CLOWSER . I am a bricklayer, and live at Merton. On the 5th of November, about three o'clock in the afternoon, I saw the mare running about at Merton, in the public read, going towards Lon
don—there was nobody with it—I saw it till it went out of sight—it was running—it was about a mile from the meadow it had been put in—the same road leads to the meadow—about five o'clock the same afternoon I saw her again—I know it was the same mare by a white streak on its face—it was a chesnut mare, and the one the prosecutor has claimed—I have seen it since—when I saw it at five o'clock it was coming in a direction from London, a very little way from the same spot, and the prisoner was running after it—I stopped it—the prisoner came and put a bridle on it, and led it away towards Wimbledon—he said that he knew the owner living at Wimbledon, and he would take her home—Wimbledon also leads towards where the mare was kept—Eyton was with me.

Cross-examined. Q. What is the prisoner? A. He lives with his father, and is a groom—he lives nearer to London than where I first saw the mare—it was running in a direction to pass his house—it was about two hours after that I saw her coming back, and he was following her with a bridle—he put the bridle on in my presence—I knew him and he knew me.

DAVID EYTON . I live at Merton. I saw the mare in the road about three o'clock, and took her to Mr. Griffiths's house, to ask if it was his—I afterwards turned her loose in the road—I was with Clowser two hours after, and saw the mare coming back, and the prisoner following it—he put the bridle on it—I knew him before—he was a groom, and was in Mr. Blake's service, but not at that time—his father is a maltster—I did not know that the mare belonged to the prosecutor.
HENRY HART . I am a constable. I apprehended the prisoner at Merton, at his father's house.
WILLIAM WEST . I am a constable of Mitcham. I found the mare at Buntingford, in possession of a person named Sydney, and delivered it to the prosecutor.

ALFRED RIX . I am bailiff to Captain Holland, Lord Holland's brother, at Molehurst, Hertford. On Thursday, the 8th of November, I went to Hertford fair, and saw the prisoner there—he said he had a chestnut-mare, and, as I knew the dealers better than himself, he wished I would sell it for him—I asked where he had got it—he said, "At Tattersal's"—the mare was swapped with George Clarke, of Stanstead, for a dark chestnut mare and eight sovereigns—I gave the sovereigns to the prisoner, and his boy took the dark chestnut mare to the Cross Keys for him—I have since seen the mare the prosecutor claims—it is the one the prisoner swapped for the other.

THOMAS HOATH
re-examined. I had had the mare about a fortnight—I had not rode it about—it had never been out but once—very few people would know that it belonged to me.
NOT GUILTY .

244.
WILLIAM CHEESEMAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of November, 40 yards of silk, value 6l. 13s.; 21 yards of ribbon, value 17s.; 2 yards of velvet, value 17s.; 1 scarf, value 5s.; 1 pair of stockings, value 10s.; 6 yards of merino, value 2l.; 10 pairs of gloves, value 1l. 9s.; 4 pairs of mittens, value 4s.; and 1 pair of cuffs, value 1s. 6d.:—also, on the 19th of November, 28 yards of lace, value 1l. 19s.; 2 aprons, value 9s.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 10s.; and 2 scarfs, value 12s.; the goods of
Wil
liam Orlando Johnson and another, his masters: to both of which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 22—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Nine Months.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

245.
DAVID PHILLIPS was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of November, 1 pair of shoes, value 7s.; the goods of
Robert Williams Pea
cock.

THOMAS PEACOCK . I manage the business of my brother Robert Wil
liams Peacock, a boot and shoemaker, in Tooley-street. On Thursday, the 22nd of November, a man came to the shop—I ran out in consequence of what he said, and met the prisoner, near Martin's, the pawnbroker's, in custody—Titchmarsh had the shoes—they were my brother's, and had hung on the door-post, in the street.

THOMAS LEWIS GREEN . I am seventeen years old, and am in the employ of my brother James, a fishmonger, in Bermondsey-street. On the 22nd of November I saw the prisoner, in company with a young man and a girl—the other young man looked at the shoes several times, and walked about the door with the prisoner, and tried to lift them off the hook—I told Titchmarsh, and he told Mr. Hall—after some time the other young man took them down, and handed them to the prisoner, who put them under his coat, and walked on—they were pursued, and the prisoner was secured with them, and taken into Martin's shop, where I saw the shoes fall down from him.

THOMAS TITCHMARSH . Green pointed out the prisoner, with a man and woman—I watched them for ten minutes, and saw them get the shoes nearly off the hook—I informed an officer, and went about my business—I
was returning, and Green called to me that they had got the shoes—I then stopped the prisoner, thrust him into Martin's shop, and the shoes fell at his feet—I held him till the officer came up.
SAMUEL JAMES HALL . I am a constable. I took charge of the prisoner and the shoes.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY .* Aged 20.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(The prisoner had been in custody more than thirty times.)
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

246.
THOMAS CRAMP was indicted
for embezzling the sums of 50l., 100l., and 50l., which he had received on account of
Charles Fossett Bur
nett and others, his masters; also the sums of 200l., 108l., and 8l.; to both of which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 35.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.
(The prosecutor stated his loss to be between 2000l. and 3000l.)
Before Mr. Recorder.

247.
THOMAS ELLIS was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
Richard Berry, on the 21st of August, at St. Mary Newington, putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 watch, value 5l.; 1 watch-guard, value 1l.; 1 watch-chain, value 5s.; and 1 watch-key, value 6d.; his goods; and, at the time of the said robbery, striking, kicking and using other personal violence.
MR. RYLAND conducted the Prosecution.

RICHARD BERRY . I am a wagoner, in the employ of Mr. Coome, of Linfield, in Sussex. On the 21st of August I was with his wagon, going from London, home—I started from the White Hart, in the Borough—I got near the Elephant and Castle at half-past eleven o'clock at night, and had got into the wagon—the prisoner called me out of the wagon—I got out, and he begun to abuse me very much, and spit in my face twice, and asked me how I liked it—I said, "I do not like it much, but I suppose I must put up with it"—he then knocked me down—I had not said any thing to him—I felt I could not stand up against him, nor had I any disposition to do so—he knocked me down with his hand—whether he had any thing in it I can
not say—my mate was at the horses' heads driving the wagon—there were three men standing with the prisoner, very near him—they stepped back on the pavement as soon as I got out of the wagon—they remained there—I did not want to have any thing to do with it—I am fifty-seven years old—when I was knocked down I fell near the wheel—I was stunned by the fall—I understand the three men who were with him lifted me up into the wagon, but I was not in my senses—I came to my senses directly after, and found my pocket was turned inside out—I had had no money there—I found my watch and guard were gone—I had had the watch in my hand, just before, as I was late, and looked at it by Kennington-gate, against the time-piece, and it was exactly right—it was just by the Wagon and Horses, below the Ele
phant and Castle, that he called me out of the wagon—I had not sense enough to make an alarm, but when I came to myself I told my mate to stop, but we could not see an officer about, as it was Camberwell fair
time—the watch had been in my fob, and guard round my neck next my shirt—it cost 50s.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. A. Was the prisoner a stranger to you? A. No, he has been for some years the Linfield carrier—I drive for Mr. Coombes, whose van is an opposition van to the prisoner's—he drives for his father—we never had any words before—his brother broke his leg in my master's employ, and they were angry with me because I took his place—I heard him swearing something about his brother before he struck me—I did not, on that, come out of my van, and ask what he meant by it—I will swear that—he called me out, and I asked what he wanted—he spat in my face, and began to call me all manner of names—I did not call him a s—y-nosed b—or a d—rogue, or any thing of the kind—I did not say any thing about his having been in gaol, or about his having been on one side of the wall, and I would try to get him on the other—I never lifted my hand against him—I applied to the Magistrate at Linfield for a warrant, and he gave it to me, and I got one from Union-hall—Mr. Bent did not refuse to give me one—the prisoner came down to Linfield with his wagon after this—I did not see him at the Quarter Ses
sions—I understood he was there—I went there, and they said it would be tried here—I never said I did not believe he took my watch—I said one of them must have taken it, I could not say which—I was quite sober.

Q. Did you ever say to any person that you never accused him of stealing your watch, but you were determined, by some means or other, to keep him off the road, the rest of his family would be of no use? A. No, never—I never said so to Peacock, a broker in the Blackfriars-road—I will swear that—Peacock came with Ellis, and wanted to make it up—I took him to be the gentleman, but he would not tell me his name—they sent for me over to a public-house—I told Peacock I could not think of making it up after being so dreadfully used—my watch was in my fob under my smock-frock—I had looked at it at the gate not three minute before—I stopped at Beckett's, and had a pint of beer among three of us—that was all I had—I did not stay there five minutes at the outside—Ellis was taking something up there—we generally call to see if there is any thing to take—he had his van there—we did not both stop there—he told my mate to stop, and said "Where is old Dick? I want to see him"—I do not know why he should spit in my face—I never had a mis—word from him in my life—I never raised my hand against him—I cannot say how long he has been in business—I have not lived at Linfield long myself—I lived at Brighton a good while—the last service I had was at the Catherine-wheel, in the Borough—I kept flys at Brixton, and kept a beer-shop in Kingsland-road, which I left because it did not answer.

MR. RYLAND. Q. How long had you known Ellis? A. Many years—I saw nobody but the three persons I have described, when I came out of the wagon, I thought one of them must have taken my watch—I am sure it did not drop—I never knew Peacock till he came with Ellis to make it up, and I refused, as I was bound over in 30l. to appear.

JOHN GORRINGE . I am a wagoner. I was with Berry on the 21st of August—I went with the horses, and he with the wagon, and opposite the Wagon and Horses the prisoner came up, and asked me where my mate was—I said, "In the wagon"—he told me to stop the horses, which I did—he then called Berry out of the wagon—there were three more persons standing close to the prisoner at the time, I saw Berry come out of the

wagon—they all four stood together when he came out, and then the three stepped back on the pavement, and stopped there—Ellis kept calling Berry a blackguard, and every thing he could think of, and spit in his face twice—I did not hear Berry's answers, but he said something—I saw Ellis hit him with his doubled fist, and knock him down—he fell just before the front wheel of the wagon—I took hold of the horses' heads to prevent their over him—the three men stepped up from the pavement, took him ip, and put him into the wagon—I saw him about five minutes afterwards was getting better then, but was very poorly still, and complained of—before we had got to Newington-gate, he called to me, and told time—I knew he had a watch about him, and a guard round his the watch went into his fob—I had seen him with the watch in the afternoon—he said he had lost his watch when he complained of his head.

Cross-examined. Q. Were hard words used between Ellis and Berry? did they quarrel? A. Berry never said a word—he did not strike Ellis at all—there is a clock at Newington-gate, where he told me the time—I had seen his watch about three o'clock that afternoon—it was Camberwell fair time—the three persons were very officious helping him into the wagon—I saw Ellis speak to them—I do not know who they were—a man named Maynard just got hold of Berry, and said, "I will help you"—I never beard Ellis tell Maynard to help him in.
Q. Were you detected the other day in stealing some peas? A. Yes, I just took a handful from Mr. Podman's stack to eat—I did not think it any harm—Berry was with me, he was in the van.

MR. RYLAND. Q. Did you eat the peas? A. No, I threw them along the road—I ate one pod—I was not taken before a Magistrate for it—if they were worth a farthing, it was as much as they were—I saw Ellis speak to the three men before Berry got out of the wagon.

WILLIAM HONEY . I am ostler at the White Hart in the Borough. On the 21st of August, about eleven o'clock at night, Berry left with his van, and Gorringe with him—he was solid and sober then—I do not know whether he had a watch—I have heard him say he had, but I never saw him pull it out.

Cross-examined. Q. How far is the White Hart from Beckett's public-house? A. About forty rods—I never saw him tipsy since he went with the team—there were two horses to the van—Ellis's van puts up at our yard occasionally—sometimes his van has one hone, sometimes two, and sometimes more—he drives for his father, I believe—his brother assists him—he did drive for Combe—I do not know Maynard.

JOHN GORRINGE
re-examined. I forgot to say, when Ellis knocked him down, that the people said, "Pull him away from the wheel," and Ellis said, "It will serve the old b—r right if the wheel ran over him."

Cross-examined. Q. Have you said that before? A. Yes—Berry did not tell me to come up and state this—I cannot say who stole the watch—I never said Ellis stole it, and I never said he did not steal it—nor that I did not think he stole it.

THOMAS MAYNARD . I am the prisoner's mate—he lives at Linfield, and drives his father's van. I remember the van stopping at the Waggon and Horses on the night in question—Ellis's van was there first, and Berry's van came up—Ellis said, "Where is Dick Berry?"—the boy stopped the horses, and said, "He is up in the van"—Ellis said, "And the

best place for him"—Berry hallooed out, "What do'you mean by that?"—he said, "Why, what do you mean about my brother Bob and about me?"—Berry then got out of the wagon and called Ellis a rogue, a s—y nosed rip, and a liar, and struck him—Ellis then struck him again, and knocked him down—Berry was very drunk—I assisted in pulling him into the van by desire of a gentleman who stood by—there was nobody with Ellis besides me—we had come from the Talbot, which is about a mile from the Coach and Horses—we had only been there a very few minutes before Berry's van came up—I never saw Ellis spit in Berry's face at all—we stopped at Beckett's a minute or two.

MR. RYLAND. Q. What time did you leave the Talbot? A.
