About ten o'clock—we went direct from there to the Coach and Horses, and got there about half past ten o'clock—we stopped there about ten minutes, and then went on our way—I did not see three men standing talking to Ellis—there were no men talking to him at all—some came afterwards—if there had been three men talking to him, I must have seen them—an old gentleman helped him into the wagon—I did not see three persons help him into the wagon—I helped him, and must have seen them if there had been—I will swear they did not—I do not think Berry was much hurt—he was very drunk—he appeared to be so when he came out of the wagon—he reeled—he could hardly stand—he was very abusive, and talked a good deal—it was not a dark night—any body could see three men if they were there—the old man had a brownish coat, dark trowsers, and a black hat—it was a clear night—he had a stick in his hand—he had not much difficulty in putting the prosecutor into the wagon—he put him on the shaft, and he crawled in.

JONATHAN PEACOCK . I am a commission-traveller, and live at No. 8, Nelson-place, Nelson-square, Blackfriars-road. On the night in question I was at Mr. Jones's, who keeps the Coach and Horses, and about ten or eleven o'clock I saw the two vans there—as I came out, I heard the per
sons standing about, say to Ellis, "Why don't you strike him again, he has struck you first, and abused you grossly?"—Berry then came, and at
tempted to strike him again, and Ellis, to defend himself, struck him and knocked him down—I imagined it was a mere drunken quarrel between the two carriers—I considered they were both drunk—I did not help Berry into the van—I saw an elderly person in a dark dress, who I do not know, do so—I did not see three men step back on the pavement—there were ten or twelve persons about when I came out, but I was not there at the first of it—the prisoner afterwards called on me, and I went with him to the pro
secutor to see if the matter could not be arranged without any further de
lay or expense, as I was daily expecting to go down to Hull on business of importance—we went to a house in the Borough-market, and sent for the prosecutor—he came, and I said it was a very unfortunate thing, could not the matter be settled—he said he did not care much about it, only he had lost his watch, which I was not aware of—I said, "Do you accuse Ellis of stealing it?"—he said, "No, I do not accuse him, but it was through him I lost it; I can't do any thing in it, you must consult some other party, for we are determined to drive him off the road, and then the rest of his family will be of no use"—that was in Ellis's hearing—finding that to be his determination, the matter ended—he took a glass or two of ale with me, and went about his business.

MR. RYLAND. Q. For whom are you engaged as a commission-travel
ler

A. Messrs. Molt, of Whitechapel, soap-manufacturers—I have 6d. per hundred for selling—I have travelled for them nine years in town—I have no salary, but a commission—I deal with grocers and oilmen in soap and spices—I have sold to Messrs. Green, of Leather-lane, oilmen, within these six months, to the amount of 200l. or 300l. perhaps, and with Messrs. Lloyd, of City-road, grocers, within these three months, to the amount of 40l. in soap—and a great many others, on account of Messrs. Molt—I have lodged in Nelson-place for eight years—I was formerly in a very extensive way of business as a grocer, in Black friars-road, facing Rowland Hill's chapel, where I lost some thousands—I was a bankrupt in 1825—I deal in spices on my own account—I have no place of business—I went to the Coach and Horses with a foreigner to take a glass of ale—Mr. Jones, whose father keeps the house, has been a friend and customer of mine many years—I think it was between ten and eleven o'clock I was there—I frequently call there as I pass by—I saw both parties distinctly when I came out—I considered them both drunk—an elderly man and Ellis's boy helped Berry on to the fore-shafts—I did not see him put into the wagon—I don't think Ellis was so drunk as Berry—I have known Ellis six or seven months—I am not in the habit of calling him Tom—I never heard that he and Berry were rivals in business—I tried to settle the matter, to save the trouble and expense of going down to Lewes—I had not heard then that Ellis was charged with stealing the watch—Berry did not say there were three other men with Ellis when he lost it—he did not describe how he lost it—I cannot say whether the twelve persons I saw belonged to the "Swell Mob"—it was rather a dull night—I did not say it was a clear night—there was plenty of light from Jones's window, but it was a foggy night, rather, not decidedly foggy—you might discern a dozen yards before you—I think, when it was all over, it could not have exceeded half past ten o'clock.

GUILTY of an assault. Aged.—
Confined Four Months.
Before Mr. Baron Alderson.

248.
JOHN HARRIES was indicted
for feloniously forging and utter
ing, on the 28th of June, an acceptance to a bill of exchange for 100l., with intent to defraud
Francis Thomas Biddulph and others.
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the Prosecution.

DAVID HARRIES JAMSS . I live at Llandilovawr, Carmarthenshire. I am a Magistrate for Pembroke—the prisoner is my brother-in-law—my sister is now dead—I had assisted him with money to a considerable ex
tent before her death—I ultimately found that he was committed to Car
marthen gaol for debt—(looking at a bill.)—the acceptance on this is not my hand-writing—I did not authorise the prisoner to sign it for me—I found that it had gone to Biddulph's bank—I went to Carmarthen prison to see the prisoner—I said, "I find you have forged my name, and you must abide by the consequences, for I will never pay one farthing of the money"—he made no reply—there was no one with me at that time—I left him—that was about the 8th or 10th of September, 1887—I went and saw him again five or six days afterwards, with Mr. Lewis Morris, the prisoner's attorney, but said nothing to him then—this acceptance bears a resemblance to my signature—the body of the bill is the prisoner's hand
writing.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. When asked if the prisoner was

your brother-in-law, you answered, your sister was dead? A. Yes, I do not consider him a brother-in-law any longer—there is still a tie by the marriage—he is a first cousin of mine besides—he is the son of a broths of my mother's—his wife died in October, 1837.

Q. Have you been in the habit of accepting bills and procuring dis
counts for each other? A. I have for him, and he has for me, up to about the year 1831—that ended in 1831—I have been in the habit of giving him blank accommodation acceptances—I think I did so in 1831, before Walter's bank failed at Carmarthen—have not done so since, to the best of my knowledge—I have certainly not done so in the last year, in no part of it—I have not done so in 1836, to the best of my knowledge—I may have done so and forgotten it—I have not such a recollection as ena
bles me to say I did not do it—I have been compelled to prosecute the prisoner in consequence of the loss of my sister, and other circumstances—Mr. Biddulph has nothing to do with the prosecution—I do not know of a person named Phillips having brought an action against the pri
soner in the Borough Court of Carmarthen—I do not know that he had the prisoner in prison for debt—I gave 20l. to get a habeas to bring the pri
soner to London—he has been in custody on civil process since August last year—he had been sued in the Borough Court of Carmarthen before I did that—I gave the 20l. about two months ago, long after I knew of this forgery—all his friends and relations live in Carmarthenshire—I never authorised my attorney to indemnify Phillips against the coats in bringing him to London—I never told bun to bear Phillips harmless in the expense of bringing the prisoner to London, or in his costs—I preferred this hill is October, thirteen months after I found out the offence—an action had been brought against me about the bills in the mean time, and a verdict passed against me—I have preferred two indictments—one it for a 200l. bill—that is the one on which the verdict was obtained against me, and on which I have obtained a new trial, on payment of costs, since this indictment—the prisoner was examined as a witness on the trial in August last—I heard him swear that I gave him authority to put my name to both bills—the trial was in Carmarthen.

Q. After that trial on which a verdict passed against you in Carmarthen, you paid for a habeas to remove him to London, and being in custody on civil process, have you indicted him for this offence? A. I did—he has lived twenty years in Carmarthen, and carried on business in a large way—I have not obtained any property from him—he gave me a nominal security—I will show it if you wish it—I do consider it nominal, as it is worth nothing—it is a mortgage, but there was a prior mortgage, which exists to the full value—I had it given me on the 8th of June, 1837—I did not know of the prior mortgage at that time—Mr. Biddulph claims it—his clerk told me so yesterday—the mortgage was for money I became security for before—I know that a fiat of bankruptcy had been issued against the prisoner—this deed recites three prior mortgages for 1600l., but there is another which I did not know of—there is 1300l. cannot be sold—he has only a life interest in it—I cannot tell the value of it—I entered into a bond of 600l. for him, to a person named Moss—I gave a note of hand for 300l. to a person, which I paid—this mortgage was given as a general security for all debts I might have to pay for him—he owes me money now—there is a time limited in the deed—I have not sold the estate, as there is a prior mort
gage—I had become security at the time he executed this—1000l. is the amount he is charged by that mortgage—at that time I had not advanced

more than 900l., but I was security for more—there was a bond for 600l., a note of hand for 300l. at Jones's, and a bill of 82l. at Wilkin's bank—it was an accommodation bill—I never had a farthing of the interest paid me on this mortgage—it was about 1829 I was security for the 600.—I know the bond was before 1830—I found he was in difficulties, and got the security to indemnify myself if I could—I went to the prisoner's office on that occasion—I did not tell him if he would give me the security to enable at to cover the 600l. and 800l., I would do any thing for him I could—he did not tell me he should want the use of my name for 500l. or 600l.—I cold him he must pay the securities off, for I would not be responsible for soy money for him—I make ft mistake—I meant to say I would not be re
sponsible any longer for the amount which I was security for—that he must pay them—what I meant to do was to go to the parties, and ask them to call the money in—I was not a creditor at that time, only a security—I lever knew that he had the signatures of three-fifths of his creditors to his certificate—I heard he was to be discharged from prison in September, 1887—he told me so when I saw him in prison—I heard it rumoured in; Carmarthenshire that he was likely to be discharged while he was in Lon
don—it was not on that that I came up and indicted him—on my oath, I did not come up with in a week of the time I beard it—I heard it on my way up from Carmarthen—I live twenty-five miles below Carmarthen—I was coming up to get these indictments preferred against him—it was some time in October, not before, about thirteen months after I had seen him in prison—I went to the different holders of the bills, to declare them as for
geries—I went first to him in prison, to know if the bills were still in ex
istence which he had forged—I knew of the bills by the holders apply
ing for payment—the first application was in September, 1837—that Was not about the 900l. bill on which the action was brought—the bill was not due at the time I went to him in prison, but I was told there were bills in existence with my signature, which I was not aware of—it was neither of these bills I was applied to for payment of—it was a third bill—that was at Carmarthen—I have kept some cases back—William Phillips holds one, and Posthumous Phillips the other—I am not aware that they are any relations to the man I gave the 20l. to go to get the habeas—Post-humous Phillips is a maltster—the bill be has is for 150l.—I have been called on to pay it—I have not paid any part of it—I have taken no steps on it—the other is for 100l.—William Phillips is the holder of that—those bills are signed by procuration—I do not know what drawing by procura
tion is—I have never seen those bills—I was called on to pay them twelve months ago.
COURT. Q. How do you know that they are not your signature? A. I know I never signed such bills.

MR. CLARKSOK. Q. Has not your wife stated to you repeatedly that you had put your name to so many accommodation bills that you did not know the number? A. My wife was very much annoyed when she found it out, but I do not know that she ever used such words as those—I will not swear she did not—I do not know what answer I made her—my wife sometimes writes letters for me—an application was made to me by Mr. Jones for payment of the 200l. bill I have indicted the prisoner for—my wife wrote a litter in answer to Mr. Jones, by my direction, in November, 1837—Morris and Son were the holders of the bill—the action was brought after I had been to Carmarthen to see Jones—I went to declare them forgeries—I did not request Lewis Morris to go with me to the prisoner in gaol—he was not with me when I declared the forgery—the only

time he went with me to the prison was in September—that was not the first time I went—I asked him to go with me—there was no statement of the prisoner's affairs and accounts gone into then—the balance-sheet was not made—Morris did not ask the prisoner to explain an item of 400l. stated to be due to Mr. James—he did not ask who the Mr. James was to whom the debt of 400l. was stated—I will swear he did not ask it in my hearing—the prisoner did not reply that it was Mr. James, his brother-in-law, now present—Mr. Morris did not inquire of what the 400l. was made up, nor did the prisoner state it was 200l.—a bill and note for 100l. due to William Phillips, and another for 100l. due to Biddulph, nor any words to that effect—nor did he state, "In all of these Mr. James is liable as the acceptor"—I have seen his balance-sheet—it was about the latter end of September, or beginning of October, that the prisoner was brought from Carmarthen—Morgan Rice James is an attorney—he has been my attorney, he is not now—I sent him to Carmarthen gaol about this, in September, 1837, as I found there were more forgeries—I was applied to for another bill, which I knew nothing of, which was forged—that was the 200l. bill of Morris I have indicted him for—I went to Haverford West, and spoke to my professional man, and asked him to go up and inquire whether that 200l. was the extent of the forgeries—I had heard of two be
fore that, held by William and Posthumous Phillips—I had seen him twice in prison.

Q. Why have you not preferred charges for those bills? A. I did not care which, I left it to my professional man to choose—my present at
torney lives in London—I did not direct the two bills of Phillips's to be brought to London.
Q. Was not the bill on Morris, which induced you to send Mr. M. R. James to the prisoner in gaol, due in October? A. That was for another 100l., which I never heard any more of.

Q. Then there seems to have been thousands according to your state
ment? A. I cannot say—I did not send Mr. M. R. James to see if he could get any admission from the prisoner—I sent him to know the extent of the forgeries—he was examined as a witness for me on the trial last summer, and he swore, in my presence, that the prisoner admitted the forgery, and the Jury found for the plaintiff.

Q. Pray have you got any security besides that you have produced, either from the prisoner, or his family? A. I have security from his mother—I got that, I think, at the latter end of 1837—I have not brought it to London—I received it, I think, in October, after I sent Mr. M. R. James to the prison—it is a mortgage—it does not state any amount—I took it after I found there was another mortgage, I mean Biddulph's mort
gage—I do not know the amount of that—I have heard it is 600l., but Mr. Hulme, the clerk, said yesterday he thought it would cover the other 100l. also—I know his mother's property lets for 55l. a-year—I have a general charge, without any amount stated—there is no incumbrance on it—she gave me that as security that I should not he injured by her son—I think Mr. Gwynne was the prisoner's detaining creditor—I did not know he was going to arrest him—he was examined on the trial as a witness—Mr. Hulme was not—the case was tried before Mr. Baron Gurney.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Before you went to the prison with Mr. Morris, had he requested of you to avoid any particular subject? A. Yes, he had—I was the defendant in the 200l. action—the prisoner was a witness.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Can you give any idea of the extent of accommo
dation-paper
which has passed between you and the prisoner? A. No, I Cannot—I can within hundreds.

COURT. Q. You say the security was given for liabilities previously in
curred by you? A. Yes, the mortgage—I was not to do any thing for him at all—if I was called on to pay the securities, that was to indemnify me, I was advised so to do by my attorney.

WILLIAM HULME . I am clerk to Biddulph and Co., of Carmarthen. I received this bill, to the best of my recollection, from the managing partner—I afterwards saw the prisoner about it—perhaps the day or day after it was due and dishonoured—I showed him the bill, and told him it was dis
honoured—I do not recollect what he said to it—it is a single bill, and among the many thousands passing through my hands, it is not likely I should re
collect—I do not know that he said any thing when I told him it was dis
honoured—I had known him eight or ten years—the bill was due on the 17th of September, 1837—it bears his indorsement—to the best of my belief it is his own hand-writing—I have seen him write frequently, and believe it to be his—he has indorsed it to Messrs. Biddulph—I have heard it pronounced a forgery—I made a demand, both on the drawer and ac
ceptor, when it became due—we gave notice of the bill being dishonoured, which the prosecutor never attended to—he called some few months after
wards, and requested I would show him the bill, which I did—I spoke to the prisoner about it, and he told me it was not a forgery—I told him the prosecutor had said the bill was a forgery—he replied, there was a con
spiracy, he believed, got up against him, but it was no forgery—that there was an attempt to transport him, or something of that sort—I did not call his attention to the signature of the acceptor, and he said nothing about the acceptance—I do not know who brought the bill to us—it was passed to the credit of the prisoner's account—the prisoner, I believe, did not bring it to me.

MORGAN RICE JAMES . I am an attorney, living at Haverford-west. Last September twelvemonth I went to Carmarthen prison, to see the pri
soner—I asked him if there was not a bill at Biddulph's bank, purporting to be signed by Mr. James—he said there was—I asked him whether there were any other bills—he said there were—he told me there was a bill of 200l. at Messrs. Morris, the banker's, and one of 100l. at Mr. William Phillips's, and another, I think, for 100l. at Mr. Posthumous Phillips's—I asked him whether he had any authority from Mr. James to sign those bills'—he said no, he had not—I saw him twice or three times the same day—I recom
mended him to make out his accounts, and get the business settled, as it was a serious case, and he promised me he would—I told him I was sent to him from Haverford-west, to inquire what bills he had forged, and he then told me the bills he had forged, as I have already mentioned—I do not know whether that was the way it occurred—I was with him some time, and on friendly terms with him—I did not know I should have to state what transpired—I have related the substance of what passed—I do not know whose writing the acceptance to this bill is—I have seen the prose
cutor write repeatedly—I do not believe it to be his writing—I should say it is but a humble imitation of it.

Cross-examined. Q. You mean by that, it is a very bad imitation? A. It is not very good—I have seen a better one—I am a distant relation to the prosecutor, and bear the same relationship to the prisoner—I only came because called on to come by the prosecutor—I am very sorry to be here—the prisoner had been confined for debt about a month when I

had the interview with him—I did not take any bills of exchange with me—I did not produce any to him—I have heard that the prisoner has done a large business at Carmarthen, as a wine and spirit merchant, but I live twenty-two miles from him—I think the prosecutor called on met to go to him on Saturday, the 16th of September, and I proceeded the fol
lowing day.

Q. I suppose, from the situation you filled between the parties, what
ever passed was friendly coversation, and in confidence with the prisoner? A. No—my client, Mr. James, seemed alarmed—he is not my client now—I did not know the prisoner was in London till he came—I was ex
amined as a witness at Carmarthen—I do not know whether there has been a sale of the prisoner's goods—I never asked him for the balance of what the goods produced, to cover Mr. James.

WILLIAM HULME
re-examined. Messrs. Biddulph sent this bill to the Bank of England shortly after it was drawn—it would be in the Bank of England in September, 1837—we applied to Mr. James for it on the 20th of 21st of September, for the first time, it was due on the 17th of Sep
tember—I am positive we did not apply before it became due—the prisoner has carried on a very large business as long as I have known him, and bore the character of an honest man.

THOMAS GWYKNE . I am an attorney, living at Haverford-west In November, 1837, I went with Mr. James to Carmarthen prison, to see the prisoner—Mr. James said to him, "John, are you prepared to pay these crooked bills?"—the prisoner said he was not—Mr. James then said, "You must take the consequences"—allow me to explain that I was going to the gaol on my own business, to see Mr. Harris, and Mr. James asked me to accompany him—this occurred just as we left—a great deal passed before, but nothing more about the bills.

MR. CLARKSON to MR. D. H. JAMES. Q. Were the prisoner's goods sold in September? A. There were two sales—I think the sale of his furni
ture was about November—I do not think it was before I went to the prison, but I will not swear it—I swear it was not a month before I went to the prison—I cannot say whether the stock of the farm was sold in September—I do not think he was made a bankrupt till the spring of 1838—I do not know who struck the docket—I have not proved any debt under the commission—there was an application made for the balance of his goods in the hands of the Sheriff, but it was not made on my own account—I did it for him to come out of prison—I did not get it—I believe it was from 100l. to 200l.
NOT GUILTY .
(There was another indictment against the prisoner, upon which no evidence was offered.)
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

249.
JOHN NICHOLS URSELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of October, 1 shawl, value 8s., the goods of.
William Wheeler, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged.—
Confined Six Months.

250.
EDWARD WILLOUGHBY was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of November, 2 pairs of stockings, value 6d.; 1 night-cap, value 4d.; 1 handkerchief, value 6d.; 2 pinafores, value 9d.; and 1 pair of drawers, value 2s.; the goods of
Henry Phillpot: and 1 gown, value 1s.; and 2 aprons, value 6d.; the goods of
Mary Duell.

DESIMA PHILPOTT . I am the wife of Henry Phillpot, of Battersea. On the 7th of November, my servant hung these things in the yard to dry—I saw them out about five o'clock in the evening, and they were missed about eleven o'clock—these are my things, and Mrs. Duell's—(examining them)—the prisoner lodged with us for a night or two.
WILLIAM REED (police-sergeant V 18.) I heard of these things being lost, and I went after the prisoner—I found him about six o'clock the next morning with them.
Prisoner's Defence. I found them tied up in a bundle.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Three Months.

251.
GEORGE STEVENS was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of I November, 2 reflectors, value 2s.; 2 lamp-irons, value 2s.; and 2 lamps, value 10s.; the goods of
Frederick Dawson, his master.

FREDERICK DAWSON . I am a carriage-manufacturer, in Long-acre. The prisoner worked for me about four months, and left on Tuesday—I missed things, and had suspected every one in the place, and last Sunday week my apprentice informed me that two lamps of mine were in a shop at the corner of William-street, Cornwall-road—I went there, and saw these lamps, with these reflectors in them—they were made for another pair of lamps, but the prisoner had fitted them up for sale—the prisoner lodged in that house.
Prisoner. Q. Can you swear to these lamps? A. Yes.
Prisoner. I can prove by five or six people that they taw me make them in Lambeth, and these reflectors too.

GEORGE HARRISON . I am an apprentice to the prosecutor. I saw these: lamps at the corner of Cornwall-road, in William-street—I firmly believe them to be my master's, and the cones inside I can swear to from their being blocked, which all lamps are not—I missed them, and could not find them.

Prisoner. There are hundreds of pairs of cones made on the same prin
ciple as these—I only finished them the week before.
JOHN LAMBERT (police-constable L 29.) The lamps were brought to the station-house, and I took the prisoner—he said the lamps were his, and he made them.
(Witnesses for the Defence.)

THOMAS ANKERS . I live at Nos. 15 and 16, Windmill-row, New-cut, and am a tin-man. These lamps, or some like them, were made in my place, three weeks ago last Sunday, by the prisoner—he does not lodge with me, but he asked my permission to make a pair of lamps there—I said he might do it—he came two or three evenings before, and on Sunday three weeks he came and finished them at my place—I went in a little before dinner, and saw him at work with lamps similar to these—I dare say they are them—they were all to pieces and bits on the bench—this come I had in my hand, or one I could almost swear was the same, and one of these lamps I can swear to—it was bruised in the nozzle in a bad way—this is the one—(looking at it.)—I have never had the lamps in my hand since they were made till this moment—I said, "You have made a botch of this and spoiled it"—"No," says he, "it won't matter"—this was three week last Sunday.

HANNAH HAYES . I am a widow. I saw Stevens making these lamp last Sunday week—I live with Thomas Ankers—he is my brother-in-law—I am sure it was last Sunday week—I saw him soldering them from a little charcoal—he was finishing them—my brother-in-law was not with me, but he was at home that day—he was out and in all day long, and had every opportunity of seeing them—I am quite sure it was last Sunday week.

JOHN LOVELER . The prisoner was a lodger of mine—he told new Sunday that he was going to make a pair of lamps—he brought them home in the evening—it was last Sunday three weeks, about six o'clock in the evening.

FREDERICK DAWSON
re-examined. I lost the cones about six weeks ago.

GUILTY . Aged 55.—
Confined Three Months.

252.
HENRY ROBINSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of November, 1 wheelbarrow, value 5s., the goods of
Henry Lee and another, his masters.

WILLIAM MILDMAY . I am foreman to Henry and John Lee, builders, of Brixton. The prisoner was their labourer—I missed the wheelbarrow on the 8th of November—in the morning I went to the prisoner's house in Robert-street, and traced the barrow a great part of the way—I there found the barrow.
THOMAS EMMERSON (police-constable V 149.) I found the barrow at the prisoner's house.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. After that did you take him at his master's? A. Yes.
NOT GUILTY .

253.
AGNES WALKINSHAW was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of November, 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 seal, value 10s.; and 1 chain, value 1s., the goods of
John Brown Sims, from his person.

JOHN BROWN SIMS . I live in Short-street, Horsleydown, and am a lighterman. On Saturday night, the 3rd of November, as I went into the Union, in Tooley-street, the prisoner came in and asked me to give her a glass—I went home with her to Unicorn-square—I had my watch when I went there—when I was coming away I missed it, and asked her to give it to me—she said she would give it me for half-a-crown—the woman of the house came up and called the policeman—the prisoner then said she never saw it—he searched her as far as decency would allow, and it was not found, but in going to the station-house it was dropped—this is it—I had paid her one shilling.

Prisoner. You said you would give me half-a-crown, and then you gave me the watch—I said I would give it you for half-a-crown—you said you did not know whether you had given it to me or not—it is an old spite he has had against me.

JOHN KELLY (police-constable M 85.) I was called—the prosecutor said, this female had got the watch—she said she had not got it—I then searched her as far as decency would allow, but could not find it, and on the way to the station-house I saw it drop—the prosecutor was quite sober, and the prisoner also, as far as I could judge.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Three Months.

254.
EDWARD HUSSEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of November, 1 boiler, value 10s., the goods of
Charles Wright.
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the Prosecution.

BENJAMIN EAGLES . I am in the employment of Mr. Charles Wright. I saw the boiler safe on the 8th of November—I missed it the next morn
ing—it is here.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Does Mr! Wright keep the Red House? A. Yes—the boiler was in the shooting-ground.

JAMES WILLIAM BURRIDGE (police-constable V 160.) I saw the prisoner with a boiler on the morning of the 9th of November, in Battersea-fields—he put it down and walked away, and when I went towards him he ran—I took him in Tooley-street, "Westminster, at the Adam and Eve public-house—I told him I wanted him for that copper boiler—he said, "It is not copper, it is iron."
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 21.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined One Month.

255.
WILLIAM JACKSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of November, 2 3/4 lbs. weight of wool, value 7s., the goods of
Mark Brown.

JOHN THOMAS CAMPBELL . I am foreman of Mark Brown, a wharfin
ger, in Potter's-fields—the prisoner was my extra man. On the 3rd of November I was in the counting-house, and saw him coming along—I went and took him by the collar into the counting-house, and he took some of this wool out of his breast—he was then taken—part of this was found about him, and this was on his person—(producing it.)
DANIEL JOSEPH HURLEY . I am in the employ of Mr. Brown—I saw part of this taken from the prisoner's person.
Prisoner. It was lying outside the gate, and I picked it up.

JOHN THOMAS CAMPBELL
re-examined. No, it was in a bale—I exa
mined the bales, and found one was cut—it was the same sort of wool as this.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Three Months.

256.
BRIDGET TOOMEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of October, 1 crown-piece, the monies of
Thomas Bryant.

THOMAS BRYANT . I am in the employ of Mr. Sherwood on the rail
I went into a shop in Southwark to buy some muffins, and put down a crown-piece—the man had no change—the prisoner followed me in, and wanted me to give her a muffin—she snatched up the five shilling piece, and said she would go and get change—I ran after her, and caught her—I asked her to give it me—she would not—I held her till the people came up.
Prisoner. Did you not drag me into the shop, and say you would give me a muffin? Witness. No.

HENRY SMITH . I am an apprentice to John Green, in Kent-street, a shoemaker. I saw the prosecutor go into the muffin shop in King-street—he put the money down on the counter—she took it up and ran out—the man said, "You go after it, or you will lose it"—he did, and she said she would not give it him.—he went to get a policeman—I and another young man watched the prisoner, and she went up some stairs—the money has not been found.
Prisoner. The prosecutor said he had been robbed by two girls before he met me, and then he asked me where they were—I did not rob him.

GUILTY .* Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Years.

257.
WILLIAM DADY and
JOHN ROBINSON were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of November, 12 glass bottles, value 1s.; 2 jugs, value 1d.; and 1lb. weight of grease, value 2d.; the goods of
Jeremiah Michael Evans, the master of Dady.

JEREMIAH MICHAEL EVANS . I live in Clapham-rise—Dady was in my employ as footman. I missed some property, and charged Dady with having stolen certain empty bottles—he acknowledged his guilt, and begged for forgiveness, it being his first offence—I said it was my duty to give him in charge—I procured a search warrant, and went with the officer—I found at Robinson's house a great quantity of bottles, among which were the two which I now produce.

ANN WENDON . I am housemaid to the prosecutor. On Wednesday, the 7th of October, I saw Dady take some glass bottles out of the stable and deliver them to Robinson, who was in the yard on my master's per
mises—I think he took about a dozen—he put them into a hamper, took them out of the yard, placed them on a barrow, and wheeled it away—I asked Robinson where he got them from—he said he brought them from Balham-hill—he came back in about ten minutes, and then he had a bundle and a pitcher with kitchen grease in it—it came from Mr. Evans's house—I asked him what business he had there—he said he had nothing more than what he paid for.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How many bottles did you first see in the hamper? A. Two or three—I never issued invitations to fourteen persons to come to my master's house—I never had but one person to see me—three people called to see the cook one afternoon—they staid a very short time—I do not remember that there was a party there on Sunday, the 4th of November—Mary Barton, the late servant, called on Sunday, and my master was in town—there were two broken jugs, an old cullander, and lib. of grease, value 3d. missing.
JAMES GRACE (police-constable V 24.) I took the prisoner in charge.

Cross-examined. Q. Produce the two broken jugs and the cullander, A. Here they are—Robinson lives not above three or four hundred yards off—I found the jugs in the yard adjoining his house, where there were a good many things kept—the cullander was in a yard, thrown out in a heap all lying together with other such property.
NOT GUILTY .

258.
THOMAS ELDERSHAW was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of October, 1 gelding, price 4l., the property of
Joseph Wilkinson, his master.

JOSEPH WILKINSOW . I reside at No. 265, Kent-street, Surrey, in the parish of St. Mary, Newington. I had a gelding safe on the 29th of Oc
tober, in Mr. Harris's stables opposite my house—I saw it safe between ten and eleven o'clock in the forenoon—the prisoner was my servant at the time, and had been so about three weeks—I did not give him authority to sell my horses—I had to go to Hackney, and he went with me to St. George's Church—I told him to go back and clean some bedsteads—I

went home between one and two o'clock in the day, and the horse and the prisoner were gone—I have not seen it since—it was a black pony with three white feet, a white blaze in the forehead, and a white speck on the back.
Prisoner. Did you not desire me to clean the horse and take it to Smithfield? Witness. Yes, but you did not do it.
Prisoner. He desired me, when I could find a customer for it, to sell it. Witness. I never did—I never saw any money for it.

JANE JONES . I am a neighbour of Mr. Wilkinson, and live opposite to him. I might know his little pony if I saw it—I saw the prisoner on the 29th of October, about twelve o'clock, take the pony out—he had the pony coming up the archway.

SIMON SAVORY (police-constable M 155.) I apprehended the prisoner in High-street, Borough, on the 7th of November—I told him it was on account of stealing a pony of his master—he said he took it to Deptford, and sold it to a person his master knew, but he did not name the person.

Prisoner's Defence. We went to Smithfield and bought another horse—he said, when I got a customer for this other one I might sell it—on Monday morning a man asked if my master had sold the horse—I said no—he said, "If you come to Deptford, I will give you 2l. 15s. for it"—they gave me something to drink, and I fell asleep and lost the money—I was not out of the Borough all the time, till I was taken on the 7th of November.

GUILTY .—Aged 18†.—
Transported for Ten Years.

259.
JOHN GILES and
JOHN GIBBS were indicted for
stealing on the 15th of November, 1100lbs. weight of iron, value 2l., the goods of
Peter Plimley, their master.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the Prosecution.

JOHN HOGARTH . I am manager of Mr. Plimley's iron-works, in the Borough. Giles was the carman—he had 18s. a week, and Gibbs was our labourer—we always keep on our premises large quantities of iron—the men have no authority to deal with it without I order them—on the 15th of this month I gave directions to Gibbs to remove some earth at the entrance of the yard at Bankside, to enable the horses to come in better—I sent Giles with the horse and cart to him—I went to the yard again that evening—the horse and cart stood at the entrance of the gate, and I heard them putting some iron hoops which are here into the cart—I put my head over the head of the cart and saw some hoops on the earth which they had just put in—only the two prisoners were in the yard—I asked what the hoops were put in for—they both said "For Ainger and Handy side," a house we do business for—I said that could not be the case, because they had some hoops of us in the afternoon, and sent their own cart for them—the prisoners then seemed confused, and proceeded to take part of the hoops out of the cart again, making some remark that they were only a few hoops—I said, "No, you shall go home with them now in the cart to the Broad wav" where our other yard is—"I will examine them there"—these hoops are broken up to be remelted—they drove the cart to the Broadway—neither of them gave me any account where this iron came from—there was some earth in the cart—there was llcwt. of iron in the cart—the
value of it is about 40s.—that was the iron that is here—it was under the earth nearly covered, all but the ends of them.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. You told them to drive to the Broadway? A. I did, and I followed them—there was no objection on their part to do it, and they put it on the machine by my order—Giles continued on the premises that Thursday evening—he came on Fri
day, and then I ordered him to go away—Gibbs was only a labourer—it was not his business to attend to what Giles said—I ordered Giles to go down with the horse and cart, but each of them was ordered by me to put the earth up—there was no iron mixed up with the earth—I saw it out up—I saw them in the act of opening the earth.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Had the iron you found in the cart been lying near the earth? A. No, at the further end of the yard.
JAMES TIDMARSH (City police-constable No. 51.) I took the prisoners on Friday, and have the iron.

GILES—
GUILTY . Aged 23.

GIBBS—
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Confined Six Months.

260.
JAMES SHUTE was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of Octo
ber, 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of
George Day, from his person.

GEORGE DAY . I live in Cumberland-street, Hackney-road. About two o'clock on the 30th of October, I was in King-street, Borough—I felt something at my pocket—I turned round and saw the prisoner's jacket stick out, and in it was my handkerchief, which had been in my pocket just before.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going along, another came and put it into my pocket.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 14.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Five Days, and
Whipped.

261.
ANN FORD was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
MESSRS. CHAMBERS and SHEA conducted the Prosecution.

ELIZABETH WISE . My husband, John Wise, keeps an oil-shop in Ab
bey-street, Bermondsey. At eight o'clock in the morning of the 8th of November, the prisoner came into the shop, and asked for a quarter of a pound of soap, which was 1 1/2 d.—she gave me a crown piece—I gave her 4s. 10 1/2 d. in change—I put the crown piece into the till, and then took it out and put it into my pocket—I had no other crown in the till nor in my pocket—some time after my husband came in, and asked for some silver—I gave him the crown piece—on Tuesday, the 13th, the prisoner came again about nine o'clock in the morning, for half a pound of candles, which came to 3 1/2 d.—she gave me a bad crown piece—I called my husband and gave it him.

JOHN WIS . I am the husband of the last witness. On the morning of the 8th of November, I asked her for what silver she had, and she gave it me—there was a crown piece in it—on the 13th of November she gave me another crown—I saw it was bad, and gave it to the policeman—I de
tained the prisoner—I marked the last crown.
Prisoner. You asked your wife if I was the girl, and she said she did not know, and she called her daughter down, and she said she knew me by my bonnet. Witness. My wife had a doubt about her.
ANNA MARIA WIS . I was in the shop on the 8th of November. The prisoner is the woman who came and passed a crown, I am certain—on the 13th my father called me down, and I saw her again.
WILLIAM WEAVE . (police-constable K 86.) I took the prisoner, and received this crown piece from Mr. Wise—he also gave me this other crown piece—I have had it ever since.
MR. JOHN FIEL . I am Inspector of coin to the Royal Mint. These are both counterfeit, and both from the same mould.

Prisoner's Defence. I met a man in the Borough—he gave me some gin and water, and gave me a crown piece, and told me to get him half a pound of candles, as he was a bricklayer, and going to set a copper—with respect to the other crown, I was not in the place.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

262.
WILLIAM SCOTT was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
MESSRS. CHAMBER. and SHE. conducted the Prosecution.

CHARLES BURGBSS GOF . (police-constable L 81.) On the evening of the 20th of November I was on duty in Tower-street, Blackfriars. I saw the prisoner in company with a young girl—I followed them to Union-street, Borough—I then went up to the prisoner, and took bold of both his hands—I called my brother constable, who took hold of Him by the throat—I saw six bad shillings fall from his mouth—I picked up five, and Brooks took up the other one—I looked at them at the light, and they were all bad.

JAMES BROO . I was with Goff. I followed the prisoner, and throt
tled him—I saw him trying to swallow something—six bad shillings fell from his mouth—I took up one, and on searching him I found another bad shilling in his pocket, and ten pence farthing of good moneys when the shil
lings fell on the pavement, I said to Goff, "These dropped from his mouth"—the prisoner said he had none in his mouth—I am quite sure they came from his mouth.
MR. JOHN FIEL . These seven are all counterfeits, and all cast in one mould.

Prisoner's Defence. I was by Blackfriars-road, and saw a piece of dirty rag, and in it were these seven shillings—I put them into my pocket—one fell down the leg of my trowsers—I took them out, and put them into my mouth—I did not know whether they were good or bad.

GUILTY .*
Confined One Year.

263.
GEORGE SANGLIER was indicted
for embezzlement.
MESSRS. PHILLIPS and CHAMBERS conducted the Prosecution.

H. W. PARKER, ESQ. I am Assistant Secretary to the Poor Law Commissioners of Lambeth. This is their seal—(producing a paper.)—this document places the parish under a Board of Guardians—I have the confirmation of the prisoner's appointment as master of the workhouse, on the 26th of June last—it is signed by me as their Assistant Secretary.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. This is the constitution drawn up under a particular Act of Parliament? A. Yes, under that Act the guar
dians of the poor have to appoint the master of the workhouse.
WILLIAM PIGGOTT . I am an army clothier, at No. 12, Old Jewry. For

a considerable time I have sent out shirts to be made by the paupers at Lambeth workhouse—the guardians of the parish are responsible to me for the return of my property—Jackson collects the money for the guardians—on the 26th of July I paid him 6l. 0s. 3d. for Mr. Sanglier the master—I paid him according to these receipts—(looking at them)—on the 14th of August I paid him 3l. 5s.—on the 24th of August, 3l. 5s., and these are the receipts, from Jackson, as having the money from me.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you pay the money yourself? A. I did—I rather think the receipts were signed before they were brought out—I rather think he gave them to me as they were, without any addition.

GEORGE JACKSON . I am a pauper in Lambeth workhouse. It was part of my business to take home linen, and receive money—I received these three sums, and I paid them over to Sanglier as soon as I went home—it appeared to me that he entered it in a red memorandum book, but I do not know—I paid him other sums besides these—I saw him take a memoran
dum-book into his hand, and he appeared to write.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you been in the habit of paying a great num
ber of sums to the prisoner? A. Not many—perhaps not once a month at any time—I had received money from Mr. Piggott, three or four times while Sanglier was there—I suppose he was there three months—I have a distinct recollection that enables me to swear positively that I gave the money to him—I paid him the same day that I received them from Mr. Piggott—I cannot exactly tell what I paid, but by the papers, on one is 3l. 5s.—I swear I paid that to Mr. Sanglier in gold—Mr. Piggott always paid me with a cheque on his banker's, and I went and got it changed at his banker's—I always paid the prisoner the same day, when I went home—I swear that I paid the three sums on the days here mentioned, in the counting-house—no one was there—it was in the afternoon—I generally went to Mr. Piggott in the morning with the goods—I have been four years in the workhouse.

WILLIAM THOMAS LOGAN . I am clerk of the guardians of Lambeth. Jackson used to receive the money for the work done by the paupers—it was his duty to hand that over to the prisoner, and at the end of the quarter the prisoner was to give me an account of all sums received—he was dismissed on the 16th of October—I saw him on the 18th, and asked him for his account—he rendered me an account of the money he had re
ceived, amounting in the whole to 20l. 18s. 11d.—I asked him for the particulars of it—he gave it me—one of his items was "4l. 4s. 6d. received from Mr. Piggott"—I have no doubt of the receipt of it—he did not give me an account of the sum of 6l. 0s. 3d. on the date of this receipt, the 26th of July—he did not give me an account of 3l. 5s., nor of 3l. 5s.—these three dates are wholly omitted in his account—he has never accounted for these sums before or since—I asked him when he gave his account, whether that was all he had received, he said it was—these receipts are in his hand-writing—it would not be his duty to leave receipts in the hands of Piggott or Jackson, unless he received the money.

Cross-examined. Q. How soon was he to leave? A. The guardians gave him two or three days—I did not perceive that he was in any confusion at having to leave so suddenly—when he gave me his detailed account, he did not say he could not say whether or not it was correct—I swear he said nothing of the kind—there was no charge of this kind made before the Magistrate—no depositions were taken—the Board of Guardians appointed

the prisoner—he was responsible to them—two or three members of the Board are here—the accounts should be audited every three months—they have not been audited the last six months—I had nothing to do with the appointment of the prisoner—he did not say that was the best account he could give, nothing of the kind—he said he was going to live in the neigh
bourhood, and he would look in, or something to that effect—he did not say for what purpose—the parish came under the dominion of the New Poorlaw in the beginning of the year 1836—the duties of the station filled by the prisoner have increased.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. This charge was not gone into at the police-office? A. No, he was there on another charge—we had not then found out this defalcation—it was Sanglier's duty to account to me, and to me only—I am sure that these several sums were omitted—he had been suspended one week before his actual dismission—he was dismissed on the Tuesday night, and I accounted with him on the Thursday—he was allowed to stay for that week in the workhouse.

WILLIAM PIGGOTT
re-examined. I paid the three sums specified—here is a receipt for 4l. 4s. 6d.—I also paid that to Jackson on the 26th of Sep
tember—that was subsequent to the other three dates—I paid that to Jackson in the same way as the others, and took this receipt.

(George Wilkinson, Esq., of the Northern Circuit, and Recorder of Newcastle; and Thomas Patterson, gave the prisoner a good cha
racter.)

GUILTY . Aged 34.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner and his wife, upon which no evidence was offered.)

264.
RICHARD FOOT was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of No
vember, 5lbs. weight of brass, value 5s.; the goods of
John Taylor and others, his masters.

GEORGE SMITH . I am warehousemen to John Taylor and others, brass-founders, in Red Cross-street, Southwark. The prisoner was an errand—boy of theirs—about eleven o'clock, on the 3rd of November, I stopped him going out of the factory, and found ten pieces of brass on him, the property of my employers—he said nothing.
(The prisoner received a good character.)
GUILTY . Aged 15.—Recommended to mercy.
Confined Eight Days; Two Days solitary.
